title: PHIL 305: Introduction to Formal Methods
text:
Lead Instructor: Brian Weatherson
Email: weath@umich.edu
Web: canvas.umich.edu
Office Hours: Thursday 9.30-11.30 (Angell Hall, Rm 2207)
Discussion Section Leader: Brett Thompson
Email: brettdt@umich.edu

title: PHIL 305: Introduction to Formal Methods
text:
Key Points

The course has four parts:

Propositional Logic;
Modal Logic;
Probability and Decision; and,
Game Theory.

Each part of the course has a different textbook.
All the books are open access; they are freely available and linked through Canvas.
There are 12 weekly assignments, due each week on Thursday at 5pm. The best 10 count for your final grade.
There is a final exam, which counts for 20%, and which covers all the material in the course.

title: PHIL 305: Introduction to Formal Methods
text:
Course Description
This course will introduce some important formal tools that are used elsewhere in philosophy. We will look at propositional logic, the logic of modals and conditionals, probability theory and game theory. Obviously that’s a lot to cover in a short time. The aim here is to make sure you understand the basics, and the symbolism, so you can follow simple applications of these tools, and you have the foundations to understand more complicated applications.

title: PHIL 305: Introduction to Formal Methods
text:
Required Materials
There are four textbooks for the course. All of them are open access, and hence free. The second is on Canvas, the other three have to be downloaded from elsewhere.

forall x: Calgary by P. D. Magnus, Tim Button, J. Robert Loftis, Robert Trueman, Aaron Thomas-Bolduc and Richard Zach. Available at http://forallx.openlogicproject.org.
Boxes and Diamonds: Ann Arbor remix by Richard Zach and edited by Brian Weatherson. Available on Canvas.
Odds and Ends by Jonathan Weisberg. Available at https://jonathanweisberg.org/vip/.
Game Theory by Giacomo Bonnano. Available at https://faculty.econ.ucdavis.edu/faculty/bonanno/GT_Book.html.

title: PHIL 305: Introduction to Formal Methods
text:
Course Requirements

There will be 12 weekly assignments. Of these your best 10 will count towards your grade, with each counting for about 8%.
There will also be a final exam that counts for 20% of the grade.

title: PHIL 305: Introduction to Formal Methods
text:

Weekly assignments - 8% each, 10 assignments count, 80% total.
Final exam - 20%.

text:
Canvas
There is a Canvas site for this course, which can be accessed from https://canvas.umich.edu. Course documents (syllabus, lecture notes, assignments) will be available from this site. Please make sure that you can access this site. Consult the site regularly for announcements, including changes to the course schedule. And there are many tools on the site to communicate with each other, and with me.

title: PHIL 305: Introduction to Formal Methods
text:
Extensions
Because we will release the answers to the quizzes at the due date, we won’t be allowing extensions on them.
That’s why we’re only counting the best 10 out of 12 assignments. People who are sick, or have other obligations, can skip up to two assignments without penalty.

title: PHIL 305: Introduction to Formal Methods
text:
Plagiarism
Although team-work, and even co-authorship, is encouraged, plagiarism is strictly prohibited. You are responsible for making sure that none of your work is plagiarized. Be sure to cite work that you use, both direct quotations and paraphrased ideas. Any citation method that is tolerably clear is permitted, but if you’d like a good description of a citation scheme that works well in philosophy, look at http://bit.ly/VDhRJ4.
You are encouraged to discuss the course material, including assignments, with your classmates, but all written work that you hand in under your own name must be your own. If work is handed is as the work of two people, you are affirming that each person did a fair share of the work. (Note that when you’re submitting work on Canvas, you have to each submit the paper, even if it is co-authored. That way Canvas knows that everyone has turned in work.)
You should also be familiar with the academic integrity policies of the College of Literature, Science & the Arts at the University of Michigan, which are available here: http://www.lsa.umich.edu/academicintegrity/. Violations of these policies will be reported to the Office of the Assistant Dean for Student Academic Affairs, and sanctioned with a course grade of F.

title: Truth Trees
text:
This lecture introduces a new way of testing for validity - truth trees.



Boxes and Diamonds, section 2.1




A way for determining whether some combinations are logically possible.
That can be used for determining whether some arguments are valid - if the truth of the premises and the falsity of the conclusion is not logically possible; then the argument is valid.





Start out writing the things you care about.
Each time one of those things implies that some other things must be the case, write those down too.
For example, if you write down that \(A \wedge B\) is true, also write down that \(A\) is true and that \(B\) is true. 
Each time there are multiple ways to make something you’ve written true, create multiple branches for those ways.
For example, if you write down that \(A \vee B\) is true, create a branch where \(A\) is true, and a branch where \(B\) is true.





A branch of a tableau is closed if it contains that some particular claim has incompatible truth values.
For now, this means that one sentence is both true and false.

…

The whole tableau is closed if every branch is closed.





If the tableau is closed, then the initial assumptions cannot be true together.
If you are evaluating an argument, this means that the argument is valid.

…

If you start the tableau by just saying that one sentence is false, the closure of the tableau means that that sentence is a logical truth.




Tableaux have two big benefits over truth tables.

They don’t grow exponentially when you increase the number of variables.

…

They can be generalised to things beyond propositional logic.

…
We are introducing them here because of point 2.



Here is something the book doesn’t make a big deal of, but is kind of important.

A closed tableau can show that an argument is valid.
An open and completed tableau can show that an argument is invalid.

…

The trick here is that it’s hard to tell when a tableau is completed in the relevant sense.
This will be easier to illustrate in practice than in theory, so let’s start building tableau up.




The system we are using is what is called a signed tableau system.

That means that every line consists of two parts.
The bigger, second, part is a sentence.
The first part is a sign, which for now is a truth value.
That is, it is either \(\mathbb{T}\) or \(\mathbb{F}\).




So each line either says that a particular sentence is true, or says that it is false.

The book for some reason includes the word ‘might’ here.
That’s misleading; what they should say is that each line says what is true given (a) the starting assumptions and (b) the assumptions we made for branching purposes.




The system we’re using also has two other distinctive features.

We number each of the lines.

…

We list why we’re writing down each line to the right of the tree.

…
Both of these are somewhat idiosyncratic, though not abnormal. Unlike the truth tables, there just aren’t well defined conventions for how to write these things out.

title: Truth Trees
text:
Plan
This lecture introduces the rules we use for building up truth trees.

title: Truth Trees
text:
Associated Reading
Boxes and Diamonds, sections 2.2-2.3.

title: Truth Trees
text:
What Rules Do
The rules tell you what new lines to write down given the lines you’ve already got.

To some extent they simply have to be memorised.
But hopefully they are all (except for the rules about \(\rightarrow\)) fairly intuitive.

title: Truth Trees
text: Rules for \(\neg\)

title: Sample Exam
text:
You have 3 hours for the exam.
Type up any answers you can.
But for things you can’t type - especially trees - write them out on paper, take a photo of them, and upload the photo.
Note that there will be fewer questions than this on the final, but the structure will be similar. (It will be about 2/3 to 3/4 the length of this.) The point of this is to give you a sense of the kind of questions that there will be.

title: Sample Exam
text:
Truth Tables
For each of these sequents, do a truth table to test whether they are valid. In each case, say whether they are valid.

\(A \vee B, B \rightarrow A \vDash A\)
\(\neg (A \wedge B), \neg (B \rightarrow A) \vDash A\)
\(A \rightarrow B \vDash B \rightarrow A\)
\(A \rightarrow (B \vee C), C \rightarrow (A \vee B) \vDash B\)

title: Sample Exam
text:
Truth Trees
For each of these sequents, do a truth tree to test whether they are valid. In each case, say whether they are valid.

\(A \vee B, B \rightarrow A \vDash A\)
\(\neg (A \wedge B), \neg (B \rightarrow A) \vDash A\)
\(A \rightarrow B \vDash B \rightarrow A\)
\(A \rightarrow (B \vee C), C \rightarrow (A \vee B) \vDash B\)

title: Sample Exam
text:
Proofs
Construct a proof for each of the following. (If you want to use Carnap, you can do the proofs at https://carnap.io/shared/weath@umich.edu/Playground.pandoc).

\(P \rightarrow (Q \wedge R), S \wedge P \vdash R \wedge (S \vee T)\)
\((P \wedge Q) \rightarrow R \vdash P \rightarrow (Q \rightarrow R)\)
\(P \rightarrow R, Q \rightarrow R \vdash (P \vee Q) \rightarrow R\)
\(P \rightarrow (Q \wedge R), P \rightarrow (R \rightarrow \neg Q) \vdash \neg P\)

title: Sample Exam
text:
Probability

A fair coin (with equal chance of landing heads and landing tails) is about to be flipped. Ankita is offered the following bet - if it lands heads she wins $200, and if it lands tails she loses $100. Do we know enough to advise Ankita whether or not she should take the bet? Why or why not?
Explain why the following decision rule is not generally reasonable: Identity the most likely state; then choose an act which maximizes utility in that state. (Hint: Describe a situation where this would lead to doing something unreasonable.)

title: Sample Exam
text:
Modal Logic
For each of the following sentences, do three truth trees: one to check whether it is a logical truth in K, one to check whether it is a logical truth in S4, and one to check whether it is a logical truth in KT4B (i.e., S5). You can use the simplified rules for S5.

\(\Box(\Box A \rightarrow B) \vee \Box A\)
\(\Diamond(A \rightarrow \Diamond \Box A)\)

title: Sample Exam
text:
Conditionals

Show that \(\Box (A \rightarrow B) \rightarrow \Box ((A \wedge C) \rightarrow B)\) is a theorem of S5.
Describe a sphere model (from the minimal change semantics chapter of Boxes And Diamonds) that shows \(((A \boxright B) \wedge (B \boxright C)) \rightarrow (A  \boxright C)\) is not a logical truth in the minimal change semantics.

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text: This lecture discusses strategies for constructing proofs that involve working backwards.

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text: This lecture discusses strategies for constructing proofs that involve working backwards.

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, section 17.1.

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
Big Picture

When you are given a proof to do, you are told what the intended conclusion is.
That conclusion will usually have a connective in it.
And when it does, it will often be good to aim to use the introduction rule for that connective to complete the proof.
Thinking about how that could happen will often give us something to aim for.

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
Iteration

The strategies they discuss in chapter 17 apply recursively.
Whenever we talk about a ‘target’ or a ‘conclusion’, that could be the conclusion of the whole argument, but it does not have to be.
It could just be something else we’ve set as a target.

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
Working Backwards: And
The \(\wedge\)I rule says

From X, and Y, infer X \(\wedge\) Y.

So if the last line is a conjunction, one strategy is to aim to prove both parts.

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \wedge B, C \vdash (A \wedge C) \wedge (B \wedge C)\)



Writing out premises and conclusion

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \wedge B, C \vdash (A \wedge C) \wedge (B \wedge C)\)



Setting up \(\wedge\) introduction

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \wedge B, C \vdash (A \wedge C) \wedge (B \wedge C)\)



Working backwards from \(A \wedge C\)

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \wedge B, C \vdash (A \wedge C) \wedge (B \wedge C)\)



Filling in rules

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \wedge B, C \vdash (A \wedge C) \wedge (B \wedge C)\)



Working backwards from \(B \wedge C\)

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \wedge B, C \vdash (A \wedge C) \wedge (B \wedge C)\)



Filling in line numbers for the second half

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \wedge B, C \vdash (A \wedge C) \wedge (B \wedge C)\)



Filling in line numbers for the final line

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \rightarrow B \vdash (A \wedge C) \rightarrow (B \wedge C)\)



Premise and conclusion

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \rightarrow B \vdash (A \wedge C) \rightarrow (B \wedge C)\)



Setting up \(\rightarrow\)I

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \rightarrow B \vdash (A \wedge C) \rightarrow (B \wedge C)\)



Setting up \(\wedge\)I

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \rightarrow B \vdash (A \wedge C) \rightarrow (B \wedge C)\)



Getting the first conjunct

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \rightarrow B \vdash (A \wedge C) \rightarrow (B \wedge C)\)



Getting the second conjunct

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \rightarrow B \vdash (A \wedge C) \rightarrow (B \wedge C)\)



Line numbers for the \(\wedge\)I step

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:

Line numbers for the \(\rightarrow\)I step

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
\(A \rightarrow B, \neg B \vdash \neg A\)



Premises and Conclusion

\(A \rightarrow B, \neg B \vdash \neg A\)



Setting up \(\neg\)I

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards

Finishing the Proof

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
Working Backwards

What if the conclusion is a disjunction?
Don’t work backwards!

title: 305 Lecture 5.4 - Strategies 1: Working Backwards
text:
For Next Time

We’ll look at strategies that involve going forwards.

title: 305 Lecture 1.1 - Getting Started
text: Introductory survey of some formal methods that are of broad philosophical use.

title: 305 Lecture 1.1 - Getting Started
text: Introductory survey of some formal methods that are of broad philosophical use.

title: 305 Lecture 1.1 - Getting Started
text:
Three Sections


Propositional Logic
Probability and Statistical Reasoning
Modal Logic and Conditionals

title: 305 Lecture 1.1 - Getting Started
text:
Propositional Logic

This is the logic of sentences that can be true or false, and that can combine to form longer sentences.
So as well as looking at simple sentences, like Nadia sings, we will look at sentences that are built from simple sentences.
Examples of such sentences are Nadia doesn’t sing, Nadia sings and Bethany dances, and If Nadia sings, Simone sleeps.

title: 305 Lecture 1.1 - Getting Started
text:
Probability and Statistical Reasoning


Sometimes we can’t infer that a conclusion is definitely true, but we can infer that it is probably true.
We will look at some tools for regimenting how and when we make such inference.

title: 305 Lecture 1.1 - Getting Started
text:
Modal Logic
This is the logic of ‘must’ and ‘might’. It has as many applications as there are interpretations of ‘must’ and ‘might’. The primary interpretations we’ll look at are:


Metaphysical
Epistemological

Moral

title: 305 Lecture 1.1 - Getting Started
text:

Boxes and Diamonds, Ann Arbor remix, written by Richard Zach and edited by me.

The three books are for the three parts of the course.

title: 305 Lecture 1.1 - Getting Started
text:
Logistics

These lectures are going to be very short.
That’s in part because it’s really hard to retain focus through a long logic video, and in part because it’s easier to manage uploads and downloads with smaller files.
So we’ll typically have somewhere between 6 and 10 ‘lectures’ each week, though each will be 5 to 15 minutes.

title: 305 Lecture 1.1 - Getting Started
text:
Access

The slides will be captioned.
The captions are produced automatically and they aren’t always perfect.
So if they can’t be used.
Access is important, and it’s harder to get right for a course like this than for other philosophy courses, so you should hold me to a higher standard.

title: 305 Lecture 1.1 - Getting Started
text:
Assessment

The primary assessment will be weekly assignments, most of which will be administered through Canvas.
Some of them, especially in the early weeks, will be on Carnap.
These are already all posted, and they will be due each week on Friday at 5pm.
There are exceptions for this week, the week after the mid-term break, and the last week of term.
There will also be an end of term exam, also through Canvas.

Syllabus

The syllabus is available on Canvas. Indeed, it is the first thing that comes up when you load Canvas.
Read it closely!!
It will tell you what we’re covering each week, and where you should be at over time.

title: 305 Lecture 3.3 - Validity
text: This lecture is about how we use truth tables to check for whether an argument is valid.

title: 305 Lecture 3.3 - Validity
text: This lecture is about how we use truth tables to check for whether an argument is valid.

title: 305 Lecture 3.3 - Validity
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, chapter 12, especially section 12.4.

title: 305 Lecture 3.3 - Validity
text:
Validity
We can also use truth tables to check for properties of arguments, and in particular to check for validity.

title: 305 Lecture 3.3 - Validity
text:
Truth Tables and Validity


An argument is (truth-functionally) valid if (and only if) every line on the truth table where all the premises are \(\True\), the conclusion is \(\True\) as well.
Equivalently, an argument is invalid if there is a line where the premises are \(\True\) and the conclusion \(\False\), and valid otherwise.

title: 305 Lecture 3.3 - Validity
text:
Example of Invalidity
The argument \(A\), therefore \(A \wedge B\) is invalid because of the second line.

title: 305 Lecture 3.3 - Validity
text:
Another Invalidity Example
Note that there are several lines with \(\True\) premises and conclusion. But the argument \(A \lif B\), so \(A \lif C\) is invalid because of line 2.

title: 305 Lecture 3.3 - Validity
text:
Hypothetical Syllogism
On the other hand the argument from \(A \lif B\) and \(B \lif C\) to \(A \lif C\) is valid.

title: 305 Lecture 3.3 - Validity
text:
For Next Time
We’ll finish up the discussion of truth tables and validity.

title: \(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) (in KT)
text:
\(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) is a theorem of KT.

So we can use all the rules, plus the special rules for T.

title: \(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) (in KT)
text:
\(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) is a theorem of KT.

So we can use all the rules, plus the special rules for T.

title: \(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) (in KT)
text:
\(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\)
Start with it being false at 1.

title: \(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) (in KT)
text:
\(
eg \Box (A \wedge 
eg \Box A)\)
Turn false \(
eg\) false into true unnegated sentence.

title: \(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) (in KT)
text:
\(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\)
It’s KT, so whatever is necessary is true.

title: \(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) (in KT)
text:
\(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\)
Both sides of a conjunction have to be true.

title: \(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) (in KT)
text:
\(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\)
Whatever isn’t true is false.

title: \(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) (in KT)
text:
\(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\)
A false Box sentence requires a world that makes it false. What can we do now?

title: \(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) (in KT)
text:
\(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\)
Line 3 is a \(\Box\) sentence, so the unboxed part applies everywhere accessible.

title: \(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) (in KT)
text:
\(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\)
And both parts of an and sentence have to be true - though the first is enough to close this tree.

title: \(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) (in KT)
text:
Philosophical Consequences

This is a philosophically interesting result.
If \(\Box\) means “Is known by X”, then it says that X can’t know of a particular proposition that it is true but they don’t know it.
Assuming that X is not omniscient, so there are some things they don’t know, this means there are limits to X’s knowledge.

title: \(\neg \Box (A \wedge \neg \Box A)\) (in KT)
text:
Idealism

Let B = “Brian doesn’t know that B is true”. (And assume, for now, that this kind of self-reference makes sense.
That’s surely true. My knowing it implies a contradiction in the way we’ve just shown.
So we all know it, because we can all follow the proof. \(\pause\)
Except wait - it’s true, and it says I don’t know it, so I must not know it.
So there’s something you all know that I don’t know.
Though just why I don’t know it is something of a mystery, since I do have a well-supported (and correct) belief that it is true.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text: This lecture talks about how and when you can flip conditional probabilities around.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text: This lecture talks about how and when you can flip conditional probabilities around.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
Associated Reading
Odds and Ends, chapter 8

Note I’m going to start with a somewhat different approach to these problems, before ending up in the same place as the book.
Very roughly, I’m going to cover the contents of chapter 8 in reverse order, so we’ll end up at 8.1 in a few lectures time.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
A Real World Problem

Imagine that 3% of men have disease D.
A man you know has no special reason to think he’s vulnerable to D, it’s not like all his male ancestors had D, but no special reason to think he’s immune to it either.
There is a test for whether one has disease D or not.
Among people who have the disease, 90% test positive.
But only 5% of those who do not have the disease test positive.\(\pause\)

This man just had the test, and it came back positive. What is the probability that he has disease D?




Testing terms

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
How To Solve These Problems

Start with a table with the states of the world on one axis, and states of the test on the other axis.
In this case it can just be a 2*2 table.
In each cell, write down the initial probability of ending up in that cell.
That will be the probability of being in that state, times the probability of that test result given that you are in that state.
The formula we are constantly using here is \(Pr(A \wedge B) = Pr(A) Pr(B | A)\).

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
The Table




Test Positive
Test Negative




Have Disease
0.027
0.003


No Disease
0.0485
0.9215



\(\pause\)
Let’s talk for a bit about how we generated it.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
The Table




Test Positive
Test Negative




Have Disease
0.027
0.003


No Disease
0.0485
0.9215




Focus on the top left cell. Why does it say 0.027?
Well, probability of disease is, we said, 0.03.
And probability of test positive given disease is 0.9.
So probability of disease and test positive is 0.03 * 0.9 = 0.027, or 2.7%.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
The Table




Test Positive
Test Negative




Have Disease
0.027
0.003


No Disease
0.0485
0.9215




Now focus on the top right cell. Why does it say 0.003?
Well, probability of disease is, we said, 0.03.
And probability of test negative given disease is 1 - 0.9, i.e., 0.1.
So probability of disease and test positive is 0.03 * 0.1 = 0.003, or 0.3%.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
The Table




Test Positive
Test Negative




Have Disease
0.027
0.003


No Disease
0.0485
0.9215




Now focus on the bottom left cell. Why does it say 0.0485?
Well, probability of disease is, we said, 0.03.
So probability of non-disease is 0.97.
And probability of test positive given non-disease is 0.05.
So probability of non-disease and test positive is 0.97 * 0.05 = 0.0485, or 4.85%.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
The Table




Test Positive
Test Negative




Have Disease
0.027
0.003


No Disease
0.0485
0.9215




Now focus on the bottom right cell. Why does it say 0.9215?
Well, probability of non-disease is 0.97.
And probability of test negative given non-disease is 1 - 0.05 = 0.95.
So probability of non-disease and test positive is 0.97 * 0.95 = 0.9215, or 92.15%.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
Solving the Problem




Test Positive
Test Negative




Have Disease
0.027
0.003


No Disease
0.0485
0.9215




We want to know Pr(Disease \(|\) Test Positive). Call this \(Pr(D | TP)\).\(\pause\)
That’s \(Pr(D \wedge TP)\) divided by \(Pr(TP)\).\(\pause\)
And \(Pr(D \wedge TP)\) is 0.027.\(\pause\)
And \(Pr(TP)\) is 0.0755.\(\pause\)
So the answer is roughly 0.35, i.e., \(\frac{0.027}{0.0755}\).

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
Practical Consequence

That test looked pretty reliable.
But testing positive only raises the probability of having the disease toa bit over 1 in 3.
This wasn’t really a quirk of the example.
When testing for relatively rare conditions, this is a really common situation.
Unless the test is really reliable, testing positive is worrying, but usually raises the dreaded probability to well under 1, often under 0.5.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
General Strategy For A/B Problems

Make a 2 x 2 table, with \(A, \neg A\) on the rows, and \(B, \neg B\) on the columns.
Work out the probability of each cell.
To do this, repeatedly use the formula

\[
\Pr(X \wedge Y) = \Pr(X | Y)\Pr(Y)
\]

Add up the values across the rows to get \(\Pr(A), \Pr(\neg A)\).
Add up the values down the columns to get \(\Pr(B), \Pr(\neg B)\).
Use the formula for conditional probability to work out the answer.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
Another Example

\(\Pr(A) = 0.6\).
\(\Pr(B | A) = 0.3\).
\(\Pr(B | \neg A) = 0.8\).
Find \(\Pr(B)\) and \(\Pr(A | B)\).

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
section: Use the Negation Rule to fill in the Basic Probabilities
text:
Use the Negation Rule to fill in the Basic Probabilities

\(\Pr(A) = 0.6\), so \(\Pr(
eg A) = 0.4\). 
\(\Pr(B | A) = 0.3\), so \(\Pr(
eg B | A) = 0.7\). 
\(\Pr(B | 
eg A) = 0.8\), sp \(\Pr(
eg B | 
eg A) = 0.2\).

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
Build the Table




\(B\)
\(\neg B\)




\(A\)




\(\neg A\)

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
Top Left Corner
\[\begin{align*}
\Pr(A \wedge B) &= \Pr(B | A) \Pr(A) \\
&= 0.3 \times 0.6 \\
&= 0.18
\end{align*}\]




\(B\)
\(\neg B\)




\(A\)
0.18



\(\neg A\)

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
Top Right Corner
\[\begin{align*}
\Pr(A \wedge \neg B) &= \Pr(\neg B | A) \Pr(A) \\
&= 0.7 \times 0.6 \\
&= 0.42
\end{align*}\]




\(B\)
\(\neg B\)




\(A\)
0.18
0.42


\(\neg A\)

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
Check




\(B\)
\(\neg B\)




\(A\)
0.18
0.42


\(\neg A\)





The numbers in the top row are 0.18 + 0.42 = 0.6, which is what we were told \(\Pr(A)\) was. So our work passes this little cross-check.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
Bottom Left Corner
\[\begin{align*}
\Pr(\neg A \wedge B) &= \Pr( B | \neg A) \Pr(\neg A) \\
&= 0.8 \times 0.4 \\
&= 0.32
\end{align*}\]




\(B\)
\(\neg B\)




\(A\)
0.18
0.42


\(\neg A\)
0.32

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
Bottom Right Corner
\[\begin{align*}
\Pr(\neg A \wedge \neg B) &= \Pr( \neg B | \neg A) \Pr(\neg A) \\
&= 0.2 \times 0.4 \\
&= 0.08
\end{align*}\]




\(B\)
\(\neg B\)




\(A\)
0.18
0.42


\(\neg A\)
0.32
0.08

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
Check




\(B\)
\(\neg B\)




\(A\)
0.18
0.42


\(\neg A\)
0.32
0.08




The bottom row sums to 0.4, as we knew \(\Pr(\neg A)\) was.
And the whole thing sums to 1, which is good.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
\(\Pr(B)\)




\(B\)
\(\neg B\)




\(A\)
0.18
0.42


\(\neg A\)
0.32
0.08




\(\Pr(B) = 0.18 + 0.32 = 0.5\). 
\(\Pr(\neg B) = 0.42 + 0.08 = 0.5\) 
Given \(\Pr(B)\) we could have used the negation rule to work out \(\Pr(\neg B)\).

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
\(\Pr(A | B)\)
\[\begin{align*}
\Pr(A | B) &= \frac{\Pr(A \wedge B)}{\Pr(B)} \\
&= \frac{0.18}{0.5} \\
&= 0.36
\end{align*}\]

So the answer is that \(\Pr(A | B)\) is 0.36.
If you learn \(B\), the probability of \(A\) falls from 0.6 to 0.36.

title: 305 Lecture 7.3 - Inverting Conditional Probability
text:
For Next Time

We will revise the rules of probability, with special focus on the rules that you use to solve these kinds of problems.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text: We’re discussing the nature of arguments, and in particular, the role of premises and conclusions.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text: We’re discussing the nature of arguments, and in particular, the role of premises and conclusions.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, chapter 1, “Arguments”.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
Arguments
Logic studies certain properties of arguments.
An argument, in the sense we’re interested in, has two parts:

Premises
Conclusion

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
Example

 

All kangaroos are wise.

 

Skippy is a kangaroo.

\(\therefore\)

Skippy is wise.


Read \(\therefore\) as ‘therefore’.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
Premises

 

All kangaroos are wise.

 

Skippy is a kangaroo.

\(\therefore\)

Skippy is wise.



The premises are the reasons that are given.
In this argument there are two.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
Conclusion

 

All kangaroos are wise.

 

Skippy is a kangaroo.

\(\therefore\)

Skippy is wise.


The conclusion is what comes after ‘therefore’ and is supported by the premises.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
Ordinary English

In ordinary English, the order of the premises and conclusion is not as fixed as it is here.
The textbook has examples where the conclusion comes after the premises, as in our presentations, before the premises, and between the premises.
The general rule is that it is introduced by a word like ‘so’, or ‘therefore’, or, if you’re really old school, ‘hence’.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
The Premise Set

 

All kangaroos are wise.

 

Skippy is a kangaroo.

\(\therefore\)

Skippy is wise.


There can be zero, one or multiple premises. Formally, we’ll say there is a set of premises.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
Zero Premises
Here’s my formal representation of (part of) the opening sentence of the Declaration of Independence.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
Zero Premises

\(\therefore\)

All men are created equal.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
One Premise

 

The cinema is closed.

\(\therefore\)

We shouldn’t go to the cinema.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
Conclusion

 

All kangaroos are wise.

 

Skippy is a kangaroo.

\(\therefore\)

Skippy is wise.


But we don’t allow this flexibility to conclusions; arguments have a single conclusion.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
Chained Arguments

Sometimes a conclusion of one argument will go to be a premise in another argument.
We will use this fact when we are doing proofs in a few weeks.
But any given argument aims to prove just one thing.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
Representation

 

All kangaroos are wise.

 

Skippy is a kangaroo.

\(\therefore\)

Skippy is wise.


When I write arguments like this, I’m merely presenting them, not asserting that they have any nice features.

title: 305 Lecture 1.2 - Arguments
text:
For Next Time
We’ll start talking about these nice features.

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text: This lecture looks at two tricky cases, and how the proofs for them work.

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text: This lecture looks at two tricky cases, and how the proofs for them work.

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, chapter 17.

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
Disjunctive Syllogism

\(A \vee B\)
\(\neg A\)
So, \(B\)

That looks pretty good; let’s try proving it.

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(A \vee B, \neg A \vdash B\)



List premises and conclusion

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(A \vee B, \neg A \vdash B\)



We have a \(\vee\) premise, so set up \(\vee\)E

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(A \vee B, \neg A \vdash B\)



I’ve already added the rule for the second half

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(A \vee B, \neg A \vdash B\)



A tricky move - we have a \(\neg\) premise so we’ll need Indirect Proof

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(A \vee B, \neg A \vdash B\)



And the contradiction comes very easily

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(A \vee B, \neg A \vdash B\)



Maybe too easily? Should we have been forced to use B?

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(A \vee B, \neg A \vdash B\)



Since \(\neg\)B got to contradiction, we can infer B

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(A \vee B, \neg A \vdash B\)



Now fill in line number on second subproof

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(A \vee B, \neg A \vdash B\)



And now we’re done.

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
Second example
\(\vdash A \vee \neg A\)

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
section: How to prove things from zero premises
text:
How to prove things from zero premises

If they are a conditional, set up \(\rightarrow\)I. The left hand side will work just like a premise.
If they are not a conditional, go for Indirect Proof.

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(\vdash A \vee \neg A\)



Writing out conclusion - but not premise because there is none

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(\vdash A \vee \neg A\)



Setting up indirect proof

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(\vdash A \vee \neg A\)



A very tricky move - extracting something from negated disjunction

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
Negated Disjunctions

The move from the previous slide is more or less compulsory.
The only way to get something out of \(\neg(X \vee Y)\) is to assume \(X\), get a contradiction (via deriving \(X \vee Y\)), and then use \(\neg\)I to get \(\neg X\).
It’s a pain, and it’s just a move you have to learn.
It might be my single least favorite part of this system.

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(\vdash A \vee \neg A\)



If we have \(\neg A\), we are basically home

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
\(\vdash A \vee \neg A\)



Filling in line numbers - note the subproof is the entire proof to this point

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
Challenge Problem

Prove \(\vdash ((A \rightarrow B) \rightarrow A) \rightarrow A\)
See if you can complete that proof in under 25 lines.

That one, like \(\vdash A \vee \neg A\), is a sign that the strategies in 17.1 and 17.2 work 98% of the time, but not 100% of the time.

title: 305 Lecture 5.6 - Two Special Cases
text:
For Next Time
No recorded lectures next week. We’ll just go over the proofs in the weekly assignment, and do some revision.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text: This lecture finishes our discussion of truth tables by looking some properties validity has in the truth table system.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text: This lecture finishes our discussion of truth tables by looking some properties validity has in the truth table system.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, chapter 12, sections 12.5-12.7.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
The Rules

An argument is invalid if there is a row on the truth table where all the premises are true and the conclusion is false. (Roughly!)
It is valid if all the rows where the premises are all true, the conclusion is true as well.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
A Relevance Failure
Is this argument valid?

 

\(A\)

\(\therefore\)

B \(\vee \neg B\)


Yes!

There is no line where the conclusion is false.
So there are no lines where the premise is true and the conclusion false.
So it is not invalid, i.e., it is valid.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Terminology
Say a valuation is a function \(v\) from sentences to \(\{\True, \False\}\) satisfying these constraints.

\(v(\neg A) = \True\) if \(v(A) = \False\), and \(v(\neg A) = \False\) otherwise.
\(v(A \vee B) = \True\) if \(v(A) = \True\) or \(v(B) = \True\), and \(v(A \vee B) = \False\) otherwise.
\(v(A \wedge B) = \True\) if \(v(A) = \True\) and \(v(B) = \True\), and \(v(A \wedge B) = \False\) otherwise.
\(v(A \rightarrow B) = \True\) if \(v(A) = \False\) or \(v(B) = \True\), and \(v(A \rightarrow B) = \False\) otherwise.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Restating


An argument is valid relative to a class of valuations \(V\) iff any valuation \(v \in V\) that makes all the premises \(\True\) also makes the conclusion \(\True\).
An argument is truth functionally valid when the class \(V\) is the class of valuations satisfying the constraints on the previous slide.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Very Technical Terminology

I’ll use \(\Gamma \vDash A\) to mean that the argument with premises \(\Gamma\) and conclusion \(A\) is valid in this sense - i.e., all valuations that make all of \(\Gamma\) come out \(\True\) also make \(A\) come out \(\True\).
The double bar in \(\vDash\) is to represent that this is a kind of validity defined in terms of valuations (or, as we’ll start calling them, models), and not proofs.
For purposes of 305, the difference between \(\vdash\) and \(\vDash\) is not important, and if this is the last logic/mathematical philosophy course you plan to take, you don’t have to worry about this.
But I like being pedantic even when it isn’t relevant to the course.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Closure

If \(\Gamma \vDash A\) and \(\Gamma \vDash A \rightarrow B\) then \(\Gamma \vDash B \pause\).

Proof: Assume this is false. So assume that \(\Gamma \nvDash B\). So there is a valuation function \(v\) that makes everything in \(\Gamma\) come out \(\True\) and \(B\) come out \(\False \pause\). Either \(v(A) = \True\) or \(v(A) = \False \pause\). If \(v(A) = \True\), then \(v(A \rightarrow B) = \False\), contradicting \(\Gamma \vDash A \rightarrow B \pause\). If \(v(A) = \False\), then \(v\) is a counterexample to \(\Gamma \vDash A\), but we know \(\Gamma \vDash A\) is true. Either way, such a \(v\) cannot exist, so \(\Gamma \vDash B\) is true.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Monotony

If \(\Gamma \vDash A\), and \(\Gamma \subset \Delta\), then \(\Delta \vDash A\).

That is, adding premises can’t turn an argument from being valid to invalid.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Monotony Proof

Assume that for all \(B \in \Delta, v(B) = \True\).
We need to prove that \(v(A) = \True\).
Assume \(C \in \Gamma\).
Then \(C \in \Delta\), since \(\Gamma \subset \Delta\).
So by hypothesis, \(v(C) = \True\), since everything in \(\Delta\) is \(\True\).
So \(v\) is such that everything in \(\Gamma\) is \(\True\).
And since \(\Gamma \vDash A\), that implies \(v(A) = \True\), as required.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Monotony Commentary

This idea, that adding premises doesn’t destroy validity, only works for logical arguments.
It isn’t true for good arguments in general.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Tweety the First

 

Tweety is a bird.

\(\therefore\)

Tweety flies.


That’s a perfectly good, though not logically valid, argument.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Tweety the Second

 

Tweety is a bird.

 

Tweety is black and white, lives in Antarctica, and lays large eggs.

\(\therefore\)

Tweety flies.


That’s not a very good argument!

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Transitivity

If \(\Gamma \vDash A\) and \(\Delta \cup A \vDash B\) then \(\Gamma \cup \Delta \vDash B\)

If some premises entail \(A\), and some other premises plus \(A\) entail \(B\), then the two sets of premises between them entail \(B\). This is crucial for being able to chain together lines of reasoning.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Transitivity Proof

Assume that for all \(C \in \Gamma \cup \Delta, v(C) = \True\).
We need to prove \(v(B) = \True\).
Since everything in \(\Gamma\) is \(\True\) according to \(v\), and \(\Gamma \vDash A\), it follows that \(v(A) = \True\).
Since everything in \(\Delta\) is \(\True\) according to \(v\), and \(A\) is \(\True\) according to \(v\), and \(\Delta \cup A \vDash B\), it follows that \(v(B) = \True\), as required.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Deduction Theorem
This is why we define \(\rightarrow\) the way we do.

\(\Gamma \vDash A \rightarrow B\) if and only if \(\Gamma \cup A \vDash B\).

Note that there are two claims here - one each direction. We need to prove each.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Deduction Theorem Left-to-Right

Assume \(\Gamma \vDash A \rightarrow B\), and prove \(\Gamma \cup A \vDash B\).
So assume \(v(C) = \True\) for all \(C \in \Gamma\), and \(v(A) = \True\), and aim to prove \(v(B) = \True\).
Since \(\Gamma \vDash A \rightarrow B\) and \(v(C) = \True\) for all \(C \in \Gamma\), it follows that \(v(A \rightarrow B) = \True\).
Since \(v(A \rightarrow B) = \True\) and \(v(A) = \True\), it must be that \(v(B) = \True\), since that’s the only line on the truth table where \(A \rightarrow B\) and \(A\) are both \(\True\).

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Deduction Theorem Right-to-Left

Assume that \(\Gamma \cup A \vDash B\), and prove \(\Gamma \vDash A \rightarrow B\).
So assume \(v(C) = \True\) for all \(C \in \Gamma\), and prove \(v(A \rightarrow B) = \True\). 
Either \(v(A) = \True\) or \(v(A) = \False\). Take each case in turn.
If \(v(A) = \True\), then since \(v(C) = \True\) for all \(C \in \Gamma\), and \(\Gamma \cup A \vDash B\), it follows that \(v(B) = \True \pause\), so \(v(A \rightarrow B) = \True \pause\).
If \(v(A) = \False\), it follows directly that \(v(A \rightarrow B) = \True \pause\).
Either way, \(v(A \rightarrow B) = \True\) as required.

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
Deduction Theorem Comments

This is a striking result.
It shows that proving \(A \rightarrow B\) is just the same as proving \(B\), assuming you’re allowed to add \(A\) as an extra assumption.
And that’s a good thing, intuitively. That is how we prove conditionals.
But it only works if you have the (very odd looking) truth table that we’re using for \(\rightarrow\).
This is the main reason for thinking, despite it’s odd appearance, that this truth table is the right one for \(\rightarrow\).

title: 305 Lecture 3.4 - Features of Validity
text:
For Next Time
We will start working on a different way to analyse arguments: truth trees.

title: 305 Lecture 3.5 - Introducing Truth Trees
text: This lecture introduces a new way of testing for validity - truth trees.

title: 305 Lecture 3.5 - Introducing Truth Trees
text: This lecture introduces a new way of testing for validity - truth trees.

title: 305 Lecture 3.5 - Introducing Truth Trees
text:
Associated Reading
Boxes and Diamonds, section 2.1

title: 305 Lecture 3.5 - Introducing Truth Trees
text:
What Tableaux Are

A way for determining whether some combinations are logically possible.
That can be used for determining whether some arguments are valid - if the truth of the premises and the falsity of the conclusion is not logically possible; then the argument is valid.

title: 305 Lecture 3.5 - Introducing Truth Trees
text:
Structure

Start out writing the things you care about.
Each time one of those things implies that some other things must be the case, write those down too.
For example, if you write down that \(A \wedge B\) is true, also write down that \(A\) is true and that \(B\) is true. 
Each time there are multiple ways to make something you’ve written true, create multiple branches for those ways.
For example, if you write down that \(A \vee B\) is true, create a branch where \(A\) is true, and a branch where \(B\) is true.

title: 305 Lecture 3.5 - Introducing Truth Trees
text:
Closing

A branch of a tableau is closed if it contains that some particular claim has incompatible truth values.
For now, this means that one sentence is both true and false.
The whole tableau is closed if every branch is closed.

title: 305 Lecture 3.5 - Introducing Truth Trees
text:
What Closure Means

If the tableau is closed, then the initial assumptions cannot be true together.
If you are evaluating an argument, this means that the argument is valid.
If you start the tableau by just saying that one sentence is false, the closure of the tableau means that that sentence is a logical truth.

title: 305 Lecture 3.5 - Introducing Truth Trees
text:
Benefits of Tableaux
Tableaux have two big benefits over truth tables.

They don’t grow exponentially when you increase the number of variables.
They can be generalised to things beyond propositional logic.

We are introducing them here because of point 2.

title: 305 Lecture 3.5 - Introducing Truth Trees
text:
Open Tableaux
Here is something the book doesn’t make a big deal of, but is kind of important.

A closed tableau can show that an argument is valid.
An open and completed tableau can show that an argument is invalid.
The trick here is that it’s hard to tell when a tableau is completed in the relevant sense.
This will be easier to illustrate in practice than in theory, so let’s start building tableau up.

title: 305 Lecture 3.5 - Introducing Truth Trees
text:
Signs
The system we are using is what is called a signed tableau system.

That means that every line consists of two parts.
The bigger, second, part is a sentence.
The first part is a sign, which for now is a truth value.
That is, it is either \(\True\) or \(\False\).

title: 305 Lecture 3.5 - Introducing Truth Trees
text:
What Lines Mean
So each line either says that a particular sentence is true, or says that it is false.

The book for some reason includes the word ‘might’ here.
That’s misleading; what they should say is that each line says what is true given (a) the starting assumptions and (b) the assumptions we made for branching purposes.

title: 305 Lecture 3.5 - Introducing Truth Trees
text:
Numbering And Annotation
The system we’re using also has two other distinctive features.

We number each of the lines. 
We list why we’re writing down each line to the right of the tree. 

Both of these are somewhat idiosyncratic, though not abnormal. Unlike the truth tables, there just aren’t well defined conventions for how to write these things out.

title: 305 Lecture 3.5 - Introducing Truth Trees
text:
For Next Time
We will start looking at the rules that get used for building truth trees.

title: 305 Lecture 5.1 - Subproofs
text: This lecture discusses how subproofs work

title: 305 Lecture 5.1 - Subproofs
text: This lecture discusses how subproofs work

title: 305 Lecture 5.1 - Subproofs
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, section 16.5.

title: 305 Lecture 5.1 - Subproofs
text:
Example of Subproof





A proof with a subproof




The subproof is the part of the proof that runs from 2 to 3.
Line 2 introduces a subproof - it is indented, and has a bar under the first line.

title: 305 Lecture 5.1 - Subproofs
text:
Example of Subproof





A proof with a subproof



Line 3 turns out not to be particularly important - subproofs just end when they end, there isn’t anything that makes it stand out as the end.

title: 305 Lecture 5.1 - Subproofs
text:
Example of Subproof





A proof with a subproof




What is important is line 4, when we return to the main proof.
Moving back up one level like this is called discharging an assumption (125).









A proof with a subproof



When we are still in the subproof, we haven’t moved back one step to the left, everything we assert is said to follow both from the premises and from the assumption at the start of the subproof.








A proof with a subproof




Once we close the subproof, we are saying that things follow just from the initial premises.
That’s the sense in which the assumption is discharged.

title: 305 Lecture 5.1 - Subproofs
text:
Rules on Subproofs

Only some very special rules let you appeal to subproofs.
Once a subproof is closed, you can’t appeal to any part of it, just to the existence of the subproof.
You can (typically) only close one subproof at a time.

title: 305 Lecture 5.1 - Subproofs
text:
What Could go Wrong?!



Bad Proof #1 - Appeal to line inside subproof

title: 305 Lecture 5.1 - Subproofs
section: Closing One Subproof at a Time
text:
Closing One Subproof at a Time



A good proof - closing subproofs in reverse order to opening

title: 305 Lecture 5.1 - Subproofs
text:
What Could go Wrong?!



Bad Proof #2 - Appeal to line inside subproof

title: 305 Lecture 5.1 - Subproofs
text:
What Could go Wrong?!



Bad Proof #3 - Closing Two Subproofs at a Time

title: 305 Lecture 5.1 - Subproofs
text:
Remember

Once a subproof is closed, you can only appeal to the subproof, not to the lines in it.
Close subproofs in reverse order to when you open them.
In any case you’ll be doing, just close one at a time.

title: 305 Lecture 5.1 - Subproofs
text:
For Next Time
We will look at the rules for or.

title: 305 Lecture 7.4 - Probability Revision
text: This is a short lecture just for revising some of the basic principles about probability.

title: 305 Lecture 7.4 - Probability Revision
text: This is a short lecture just for revising some of the basic principles about probability.

title: 305 Lecture 7.4 - Probability Revision
text:
Associated Reading
None - this is just revision

title: 305 Lecture 7.4 - Probability Revision
text:
The Negation Rule

All logical truths have probability 1, so \(\Pr(A \vee \neg A) = 1\). 
If \(X\) and \(Y\) are exclusive, then \(\Pr(X \vee Y) = \Pr(X) + \Pr(Y)\). 
\(A\) and \(\neg A\) are exclusive. 
So, from 1, 2, 3, we get \(\Pr(A) + \Pr(\neg A) = 1\). 
So, from 4, we get \(\Pr(\neg A) = 1 - \Pr(A)\).

title: 305 Lecture 7.4 - Probability Revision
text:
The Multiplication Rule
By definition,
\[
\Pr(A | B) = \frac{\Pr(A \wedge B)}{\Pr(B)}
\]
Multiplying both sides by \(\Pr(B)\) gives us
\[
\Pr(A \wedge B) = \Pr(A | B)\Pr(B)
\]

title: 305 Lecture 7.4 - Probability Revision
text:
Another Addition Rule

\(B\) is logically equivalent to \((A \wedge B) \vee (\neg A \wedge B)\). 
So, \(\Pr(B) = \Pr((A \wedge B) \vee (\neg A \wedge B))\). 
\((A \wedge B)\) and \((\neg A \wedge B)\) are exclusive. 
So \(\Pr((A \wedge B) \vee (\neg A \wedge B)) = \Pr(A \wedge B) + \Pr(\neg A \wedge B)\). 
By the multiplication rule, \(\Pr(A \wedge B) = \Pr(B | A)\Pr(A)\). 
Also by the multiplication rule, \(\Pr(\neg A \wedge B) = \Pr(B | \neg A)\Pr(\neg A)\). 
Putting all these together, we get

\[
\Pr(B) = \Pr(B | A)\Pr(A) + \Pr(B | \neg A)\Pr(\neg A)
\]

title: 305 Lecture 7.4 - Probability Revision
text:
Another Conditional Probability Rule
Putting that formula for \(\Pr(B)\) into the definition of conditional probability, we get
\[
Pr(A | B) = \frac{\Pr(A \wedge B)}{\Pr(B | A)\Pr(A) + \Pr(B | \neg A)\Pr(\neg A)}
\]

title: 305 Lecture 7.4 - Probability Revision
text:
Yet Another Conditional Probability Rule
\[\begin{align*}
\Pr(B | A) \times \frac{\Pr(A)}{\Pr(B)} &= \frac{\Pr(B \wedge A)}{\Pr(A)}  \times \frac{\Pr(A)}{\Pr(B)} \\
&= \frac{\Pr(A \wedge B)}{\Pr(A)}  \times \frac{\Pr(A)}{\Pr(B)}  \\
&= \frac{\Pr(A \wedge B)}{\Pr(B)} \\
&= \Pr(A | B)
\end{align*}\]

title: 305 Lecture 7.4 - Probability Revision
text:
Yet Another Conditional Probability Rule
Or, as it is usually written
\[
Pr(A | B) = \frac{\Pr(B | A)\Pr(A)}{\Pr(B)}
\]

title: 305 Lecture 7.4 - Probability Revision
text:
For Next Time

We will look at a more complicated example of inverting conditional probabilities.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text: We’re going to get a little clearer on the notions of ‘form’ and ‘structure’ from last time.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text: We’re going to get a little clearer on the notions of ‘form’ and ‘structure’ from last time.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, chapter 4, “First Steps to Symbolization”.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Definition
An argument is valid when

The truth of the premises guarantees the truth of the conclusion.
Equivalently, when it is impossible for the premises to be true and the conclusion not true.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Formal Validity
An argument is formally valid if

It is valid; and
Any argument of the same form is valid.

In those cases, we infer that it is valid because of its form.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Three Big Questions About Form


Which words get treated as part of the form, and which get replaced by symbols when converting into formal notation?
Which words have the same meaning and should be replaced by the same symbol, and which should be treated differently?
How do we break the sentence into its constituent parts?

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Part of the Form
I’m going to have a fairly pluralist, pragmatist view on this question.

This is not to say that pluralism or pragmatism is right - it’s just that it’s what I’ll adopt. (It is to say that I think it’s a reasonable approach.)
For some purposes the ‘formal words’ are very few, like ‘and’, ‘or’, ‘not’ etc.
For other purposes the set is more expansive.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Part of the Form

If you are studying the logic of causation, you might want to say that ‘caused’ is a formal word.
And that would mean any two arguments that have this structure are of the same form.


 

A caused B.

 

B caused C.

\(\therefore\)

A caused C.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Part of the Form

But for other purposes, ‘caused’ is just another binary relation between events.
So those arguments will have the same form as these ones.


 

A happened near B.

 

B happened near C.

\(\therefore\)

A happened near C.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Part of the Form

What I mean by having a ‘pluralist, pragmatist’ view about form is that there is no objectively correct answer about whether these are the same form or not.
For some purposes it will be helpful to treat them as having the same form.
For other purposes it will not be.
We’re going to start with a notion of form where lots and lots of things have the same form, so very few arguments are valid in virtue of form.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Three Big Questions About Form

Which words get treated as part of the form, and which get replaced by symbols when converting into formal notation?
Which words have the same meaning and should be replaced by the same symbol, and which should be treated differently?
How do we break the sentence into its constituent parts?

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Same/Different
There are problems in both directions here.

Sometimes we want to treat words with different spelling as representing the same meaning - e.g., ‘kangaroo’ and ‘kangaroos’.
And sometimes we want to treat words with the same spelling as expressing different meanings.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Relating the First Two Questions
Some kinds of ambiguity are ‘resolved’ by treating the word as part of the formal system. Consider two possible interpretations of this sentence.

Nothing is better than world peace

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
“Nothing is better than world peace”


There is no thing such that it is better than world peace.
It is better that there is nothing than that there is world peace.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Ambiguity and Form

If you include words like ‘nothing’ as formal words, then the two readings of the sentence will have different formal representations.
And the logic called ‘predicate logic’ does exactly that; it treats ‘nothing’ as one of the formal words.
We’re not covering that in this course, though you have have covered it elsewhere.
Some more expansive accounts of what should be a formal word are moved by the thought that treating more words as formal removes some possible ambiguities.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Three Big Questions About Form

Which words get treated as part of the form, and which get replaced by symbols when converting into formal notation?
Which words have the same meaning and should be replaced by the same symbol, and which should be treated differently?
How do we break the sentence into its constituent parts?

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
Three Formal Tools


Replacing words/sentences with letters.
Using parentheses.
Replacing ‘formal words’ with symbols.

title: 305 Lecture 2.1 - Argument Forms
text:
For Next Time
We’ll look at how propositional logic carries out these three tasks.

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text: This lecture introduces the two rules for \(\wedge\).

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text: This lecture introduces the two rules for \(\wedge\).

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, section 16.3.

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text:
Reasoning from And sentences
If you know that it snowed in Detroit and it snowed in Ann Arbor, there are two natural things you can infer. 

It snowed in Detroit. 
It snowed in Ann Arbor

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text:
And-Elimination

And-elimination, or \(\wedge\)E, is the formal version of the idea behind the last slide.
It is in fact a pair of rules.
The first says that from a conjunction you can infer the first conjunct.
The second says that from a conjunction you can infer the second conjunct.

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text:
And-Elimination the first



First Form of And-Elimination

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text:
And-Elimination the second



Second Form of And-Elimination

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text:
A Key Constraint

Just like with trees, these rules only apply to whole lines.
So you can only apply \(\wedge\)E to a line if it has \(\wedge\) as its main connective.
Remember, \(\wedge\) is the main connective if there is a well formed sentence either side of it.

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text:
Reasoning to an And sentence
How might we prove a conjunctive sentence, say that it snowed in Detroit and it snowed in Ann Arbor? There are a lot of ways we could do it, but the most obvious involves:

Proving that it snowed in Detroit.
Proving that it snowed in Ann Arbor.
Declaring victory.

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text:
And-Introduction

And-introduction, or \(\wedge\)I, is the formal version of the idea behind the last slide.
It says that if you have a pair of sentences, you can infer the conjunction of those two sentences.
It doesn’t matter which order the sentences appear in the proof.

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text:
And-Introduction



And-Elimination

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text:
A Proof





Our first proof




This proof starts with one premise.
The next four lines consist of taking that premise apart.
And the next two consist of putting it back together, the way we want.

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text:
Where We’re At

What I care about for now is that you understand how to read this proof.
Figuring out how to construct a proof like this is harder, and that’s something we’ll spend a lot of time on next week.
Natural deduction proofs should be much easier to read than to write.

title: 305 Lecture 4.6 - Rules for And
text:
For Next Time

We will look at 16.4, on the rules for ‘if’.

title: 305 Lecture 4.4 - Introducing Natural Deduction
text: This lecture introduces the proof system called Natural Deduction.

title: 305 Lecture 4.4 - Introducing Natural Deduction
text: This lecture introduces the proof system called Natural Deduction.

title: 305 Lecture 4.4 - Introducing Natural Deduction
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, chapter 15.

title: 305 Lecture 4.4 - Introducing Natural Deduction
text:
What is Natural Deduction


A proof system that looks like reasoning in natural language
Every step is an inference that conforms to one of a small number of good rules.

title: 305 Lecture 4.4 - Introducing Natural Deduction
text:
Advantages


The results look more natural.
The results feel more philosophically significant.
The length of proofs grows more or less linearly with the complexity of the argument, not exponentially.
The method can be generalised well beyond basic propositional logic.

title: 305 Lecture 4.4 - Introducing Natural Deduction
text:
Tables, Trees and Proofs

The last two advantages are really advantages of natural deduction over tables.
They aren’t really advantages over trees.

title: 305 Lecture 4.4 - Introducing Natural Deduction
text:
Disadvantages


This is a one-way method; it can’t be used to prove invalidity.
Constructing proofs is hard.

title: 305 Lecture 4.4 - Introducing Natural Deduction
text:
For Next Time

We will look at 16.1, on the idea of a proof.

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text: We’re going to look at how and why we can iterate the translation procedures we’ve been investigating.

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text: We’re going to look at how and why we can iterate the translation procedures we’ve been investigating.

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, chapter 6, “Sentences of TFL”

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
Recursion
The language of propositional logic has some fairly simple composition rules.

It says what the basic sentences are.
It has some rules saying that if some things are sentences, so are some other things.

The effect is that there are an infinity of possible sentences.

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
Natural Language Recursion
As speakers of a human language, you’re used to this kind of recursion. All of these are sentences.


It will rain.
Alex thinks that it will rain.
Kim thinks that Alex thinks that it will rain.
Alex thinks that Kim thinks that Alex thinks that it will rain.
And so on, to infinity, without adding any more words.

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
Recursive Rule

If S is a sentence, and N is a name, then N thinks that S is a sentence.
Note that the output of this rule can be the input to a new instance of it.

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
Formal Language Recursion

The letters \(P, Q, R...\) are sentences.
If S and T are sentences, then so are:


\(\neg S\)
\(S \vee T\)
\(S \wedge T\)
\(S \rightarrow T\)
\(S \leftrightarrow T\)

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
Multiple Steps
So these are all sentences. (Note that I’m playing fast and loose with parentheses here.)

\(P\)
\(Q\)
\(P \wedge Q\)
\(Q \rightarrow (P \wedge Q)\)
\(\neg P\)
\(Q \vee \neg P\)
\((Q \rightarrow (P \wedge Q)) \leftrightarrow (Q \vee \neg P)\)

The last one follows from the fact that 4 and 6 are sentences.

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
Main Connective
For any sentence you can make, there will be a ‘last step’ in the demonstration that it is a sentence.

That last step will involve copying down 1 or 2 other sentences, and adding a connective.
On the previous slide, you copy down 4 and 6, and put a \(\leftrightarrow\) between them.
That connective you add is the main connective of the sentence.
It covers all the material in the sentence.

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
Main Connective
A binary connective is the main connective if (and only if) either side of it are two complete sentences.

\(P \wedge (Q \rightarrow R)\)

The \(\wedge\) is the main connective because either side of it are

\(P\)
\((Q \rightarrow R)\)

And they are both sentences.

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
Main Connective
A binary connective is the main connective if (and only if) either side of it are two complete sentences.

\(P \wedge (Q \rightarrow R)\)

The \(\rightarrow\) is not the main connective because either side of it are

\(P \wedge (Q\)
\(R)\)

And they are not both sentences.

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
A Worked Example



Step 1

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
A Worked Example



Step 2

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
A Worked Example



Step 3

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
A Worked Example



Step 4

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
A Worked Example



Step 5

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
A Worked Example



Step 6

title: 305 Lecture 2.3 - Symbolization and Recursion
text:
For Next Time

We are going to start on how these connectives help us figure out the truth value of longer sentences.
And we’re going to use that to analyse arguments.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text: This lecture is about how to build more complicated truth tables than we have looked at so far.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text: This lecture is about how to build more complicated truth tables than we have looked at so far.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, chapters 10 and 11.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
The Example
We are going to work out the truth table for this sentence:

\((A \vee \neg B) \rightarrow (B \rightarrow (A \wedge C))\)

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
How Many Rows


How many rows should there be in the truth table?
There are three (3) atomic sentences, so there should be \(2^3 = 8\) rows.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Laying Out the Rows

The convention for these is a bit odd.
Here’s one way to think about it.
For the left-most column you fill the first half of the rows with \(\True\) and then the second half of the rows with \(\False\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text: First Column

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Second Column

Then the second column has one quarter \(\True\), followed by one quarter \(\False\), followed by one quarter \(\True\), followed by one quarter \(\False\).
In this case that means we alternate every two rows.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text: Second Column

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Third Column

From now on you do half as many rows between changes.
In this table we did 4 rows with one value then 4 of another for column 1, 2 with one value then 2 with another for column 2, and now alternate every row for column 3.
It’s helpful to know the full algorithm in case you ever have to do this with 5 or more variables.
But I won’t do that in this course.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text: Third Column

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Parsing the Sentence
Now we need to go back to our sentence.

\((A \vee \neg B) \rightarrow (B \rightarrow (A \wedge C))\)

What is its main connective? 

It’s the first \(\rightarrow\). The sentence is of the form \(D \rightarrow E\), where \(D\) is \((A \vee \neg B)\) and \(E\) is \((B \rightarrow (A \wedge C))\)

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Building Up
So eventually, we will have the truth value for the whole sentence under the first \(\rightarrow\).

But that’s some distance away.
While that’s where we want to get to, we have to build from the inside out.
The first thing to do is to repeat the values for the atomic sentences.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Atomic Replicator
What can we fill in immediately?

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Next Steps

We have enough on the table to include the values for \(\neg B\).
And we have enough on the table to include the values for the \(A \wedge C\) on the far right.
We’ll do these in order.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Negation
Everywhere \(B\) is \(\True\), \(\neg B\) is \(\False\), so let’s include all of those.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Negation (cont)
Everywhere \(B\) is \(\False\), \(\neg B\) is \(\True\), so let’s include all of those.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Conjunction
If \(A, C\) are both \(\True\), so is \(A \wedge C\). So let’s include those.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Conjunction (cont)
And \(A \wedge C\) is false everywhere else.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Complex Disjunction

The next step is combining the values of \(A\) and \(\neg B\) to get the value of \(A \vee \neg B\).
The main thing to remember here is what your inputs are.
In this case it’s not too confusing; it’s the values immediately to either side of the \(\vee\).
But that won’t be the general case.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Disjunction
When \(A\) is \(\True\), so is \(A \vee \neg B\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Disjunction (cont)
And when \(\neg B\) is \(\True\), so is \(A \vee \neg B\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Disjunction (part III)
Otherwise, \(A \vee \neg B\) is \(\False\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Conditional

Now we have to do \(B \rightarrow (A \wedge C)\).
We have to remember the table for \(\rightarrow\) - TFTT.
And we have to remember that what’s on the right-hand side of this conditional is a complex sentence: \(A \wedge C\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Conditional Terminology

It’s helpful to recall our distinctive terminology for conditionals
We’ll often call the left-hand side of a conditional the antecedent. (‘Ante’ for before, if that helps.) 
And we’ll call the right-hand side the consequent (i.e., what comes after).
We won’t have fancy distinct terminology for the left-hand and right-hand sides of other sentences, because they are symmetric.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Row 1
\(B\) is \(\True\), \(A \wedge C\) is \(\True\), so this is \(\True \rightarrow \True\), i.e., \(\True\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Row 2
\(B\) is \(\True\), \(A \wedge C\) is \(\False\), so this is \(\True \rightarrow \False\), i.e., \(\False\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Row 3
\(B\) is \(\False\), \(A \wedge C\) is \(\True\), so this is \(\False \rightarrow \True\), i.e., \(\True\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Row 4
\(B\) is \(\False\), \(A \wedge C\) is \(\False\), so this is \(\False \rightarrow \False\), i.e., \(\True\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Row 5
\(B\) is \(\True\), \(A \wedge C\) is \(\False\), so this is \(\True \rightarrow \False\), i.e., \(\False\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Row 6
\(B\) is \(\True\), \(A \wedge C\) is \(\False\), so this is \(\True \rightarrow \False\), i.e., \(\False\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Rows 7 and 8
\(B\) is \(\False\), \(A \wedge C\) is \(\False\), so this is \(\False \rightarrow \False\), i.e., \(\False\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Almost Done

Now we just need to put the two parts together.
We have a conditional whose left-hand side, the antecedent, is \(A \vee \neg B\).
And the right-hand side, the consequent, is \(B \rightarrow (A \wedge C)\).
In each row we’ve computed the truth values for the antecedent and consequent.
Now it’s a matter of just looking up how they combine.
Remember that the truth table for \(\rightarrow\) is TFTT.
To help, I’ve started by putting in blue the columns for the antecedent and consequent.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Getting There
Putting the two relevant columns in blue to make them stand out.

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Row 1
That’s \(\True \rightarrow \True\), i.e., \(\True\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Row 2
That’s \(\True \rightarrow \False\), i.e., \(\False\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Row 3
That’s \(\True \rightarrow \True\), i.e., \(\True\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Row 4
That’s also \(\True \rightarrow \True\), i.e., \(\True\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Rows 5 and 6
That’s \(\False \rightarrow \False\), i.e., \(\True\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Rows 7 and 8
That’s \(\True \rightarrow \True\), i.e., \(\True\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
Summing Up
It’s true everywhere except when \(A, B\) are both \(\True\), and \(C\) is \(\False\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.6 - Complicated Truth Tables
text:
For Next Week

We’ll start on analysing arguments using truth tables.
Remember to do the assignment by Friday 5pm.

title: 305 Lecture 4.2 - Examples of Truth Trees
text: This lecture goes over some examples of truth trees.

title: 305 Lecture 4.2 - Examples of Truth Trees
text: This lecture goes over some examples of truth trees.

title: 305 Lecture 4.2 - Examples of Truth Trees
text:
Associated Reading
Boxes and Diamonds, section 2.4.

This is a tableau for showing \(A \rightarrow (A \vee B)\) is a logical truth.

title: 305 Lecture 4.2 - Examples of Truth Trees
text:
Ticks and Crosses

I’ve stared including \(\checkmark\) on lines.
That’s just a reminder that I’m done with that line.
It’s not essential, but it’s useful.

title: 305 Lecture 4.2 - Examples of Truth Trees
text:
Ticks and Crosses

It’s useful in part because you don’t always want to apply rules in order.
In particular, you want to apply branching rules after non-branching rules.
But if you do that, it’s easy to forget which lines you still need to apply.
So the tick marks help.

title: 305 Lecture 4.2 - Examples of Truth Trees
text:
Ticks and Crosses

The crosses at the end, saying which branches are closed, are essential.


Here is a tableau for showing that \(A \rightarrow B, \neg B \vdash \neg A\) is valid.

Here is a tableau for showing that \(A \rightarrow B, \neg A \vdash \neg B\) is invalid.
This one is over the top - since both branches are open. You only need one open branch.

Here’s one for the argument \(A \vee B \vdash A\)
The right hand branch is open, so the whole tableau is open.

Here’s one for the obviously invalid \(A \vee B \vdash \neg (C \vee D)\), to make a point about branching.

title: 305 Lecture 4.2 - Examples of Truth Trees
text:
For Next Time
We will look at some more worked examples.

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text: This lecture is the truth tables for the basic connectives.

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text: This lecture is the truth tables for the basic connectives.

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text:
Associated Reading

We’re still working through forall x chapters 9-11.
This is primarily about chapter 9.
We’re not going to cover biconditionals here (or elsewhere in this course).

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text:
Four Main Connectives

Building truth tables requires, unfortunately, a small amount of memorization.
In particular, you just have to memorize the truth tables for each of the connectives.
Equally unfortunately, justifying yourself using truth tables requires justifying these basic tables.
And as we’ll see, that’s not trivial.
But that’s for much down the line - let’s learn how to use these first, then we’ll get to justifying them.

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text:
Negation Table
You should read it as saying that if \(A\) is \(\True\) then \(\neg A\) is \(\False\), and if \(A\) is \(\False\), then \(\neg A\) is \(\True\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text: The Conjunction Table

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text:
Conjunction in Words

A conjunction is \(\True\) if both conjuncts are \(\True\), and is \(\False\) otherwise.

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text: The Disjunction Table

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text:
Disjunction in Words

A disjunction is \(\True\) if either disjunct is \(\True\), and is \(\False\) otherwise.

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text: The Conditional Table

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text:
Material Implication
Note that these three sentences have exactly the same table.
This conditional is sometimes called material implication.

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text:
Oddities
It is certainly an odd interpretation of ‘if’ that makes these sentences turn out true.

If I am 200 years old, then Michigan is part of Canada.
If I am in Los Angeles, then I am in Ann Arbor.

But they are both true on this table.

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text:
Arguments

It turns out that interpreting the conditional this way makes the most sense of the role of conditionals in certain arguments, in particular to do with disjunctive syllogism.
There is an allusion to this at the end of chapter 1 of Boxes and Diamonds.

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
text:
Arguments
The big advantage of thinking of ‘if’ this way is that it guarantees that for any value of \(A, B, C\), these two arguments agree on validity - that is, they are either both valid or both invalid.

\(A, B \vdash C\)


\(A \vdash B \rightarrow C\)

And plausibly those should be the same. \(A\) suffices for \(B \rightarrow C\) just in case \(A\) and \(B\) together suffice for \(C\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.5 - Basic Truth Tables
