text:
For Next Time
We’ll talk about how to use these basic truth tables to build larger truth tables.

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text: To talk about what a model for a modal logic is.

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text: To talk about what a model for a modal logic is.

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text:
Associated Reading

Boxes and Diamonds, section 3.3 and 3.4.

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text:
Worlds
We start with Leibniz’s idea that necessity is truth in all possible worlds.

Leibniz was interested in metaphysical necessity, so we’ll have to qualify this a little, but it’s a good idea.
So instead of saying that each proposition simply has a truth value, we’ll say that there are many worlds, and at each world each proposition has a truth value.
But don’t assume that propositions have the same truth value at each world.
In one world I might be standing, and in another world I might be sitting.

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text:
What Are Worlds
We are well and truly not going to get into the metaphysics of worlds here.

Indeed, they need not even be anything like possible worlds in the sense that metaphysicians usually care about.
They might, for instance, be different times.
All we care about is that they are things at which propositions can be true or false.

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text:
Valuations
A valuation function tells us which worlds atomic sentences are true at.

These can be completely arbitrary; we don’t put any restrictions on them.

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text:
Truth at a World
We want more generally a function that tells us whether a sentence is true at a particular world.

For sentences built up using \(\wedge, \vee, \rightarrow, \neg\), this is relatively easy.
We just keep on using truth tables.
So if at world \(w\), \(A\) is true and \(B\) is false, then \(A \wedge B\) is false and \(A \vee B\) is true.

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text:
Modal Values
We also need values for these sentences:

\(\Box A\)
\(\Diamond A\)

It turns out these are more complicated - but not much more complicated.

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text:
Accessibility
The last part of our model is an accessibility relation between worlds.

Again, this can be completely arbitrary.
We don’t yet put any restrictions on it.
Notably, we don’t assume that it is reflexive, symmetric or transitive

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text:
Properties of Relations

\(R\) is reflexive iff for all \(x\), \(xRx\).
\(R\) is symmetric iff for all \(x, y\), if \(xRy\) then \(yRx\).
\(R\) is transitive iff for all \(x, y, z\) if \(xRy\) and \(yRz\) then \(xRz\).

A lot of relations we care about have one or more of these properties, but not all do. Consider, for example, admires as an example of a relation with none of them.

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text:
Truth of Modal Formulas
A sentence \(\Box A\) is true at a world \(x\) just in case the following condition is met:

For all worlds \(y\) such that \(xRy\), \(A\) is true at world \(y\).

A sentence \(\Diamond A\) is true at a world \(x\) just in case the following condition is met:

For some world \(y\) such that \(xRy\), \(A\) is true at world \(y\).

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text:
Modal Truth

Something is necessarily true iff it is true everywhere that is accessible.
Something is possibly true iff it is true somewhere accessible. 

We get back the Leibnizian idea that necessity is truth in all possible worlds if we assume the accessibility relation is the universal relation, i.e., \(xRy\) for all \(x, y\).

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text:
Metaphysical Necessity
On this Leibnizian model, where all worlds can access all worlds, iterated modalities are rather uninteresting. These three sentences are true in the same worlds/models.

\(\Box A\)
\(\Box \Box A\)
\(\Diamond \Box A\)

That’s because if \(\Box A\) is true at any world, then it is true at all worlds. In the general case, where we do not assume that \(R\) is universal, these are not equivalent.

title: 305 Lecture 11.2 - Truth in Modal Logic
text:
For Next Time
We’ll talk about the relationship between boxes and diamonds.

title: 305 Lecture 13.1 - Two Kinds of Conditionals
text: Starting the discussion of conditionals.

title: 305 Lecture 13.1 - Two Kinds of Conditionals
text: Starting the discussion of conditionals.

title: 305 Lecture 13.1 - Two Kinds of Conditionals
text:
Associated Reading

Boxes and Diamonds, chapter 6

title: 305 Lecture 13.1 - Two Kinds of Conditionals
text:
Compare These Examples

If Shakespeare didn’t write Hamlet, then someone else did.
If Shakespeare hadn’t written Hamlet, then someone else would have. 

Intuitively, 1 is true and 2 is false. 

So it must be wrong to write both of them as \(\neg A \rightarrow B\).

title: 305 Lecture 13.1 - Two Kinds of Conditionals
text:
Terminology

If Shakespeare didn’t write Hamlet, then someone else did.
If Shakespeare hadn’t written Hamlet, then someone else would have.

There are some common, if misleading, names for these kinds of conditionals.

1 is called an indicative conditional.
2 is called a subjunctive or counterfactual conditional

title: 305 Lecture 13.1 - Two Kinds of Conditionals
text:
What’s in a Name

Apparently 2 isn’t really subjunctive, though you’d have to speak to a language teacher to explain precisely why this is so.
The class of sentences that 2 is meant to pick out are all counter to the facts either, as examples like this show.


If Billy had stolen the cookies from the cookie jar, then we would have found exactly the clues that we actually did find.

title: 305 Lecture 13.1 - Two Kinds of Conditionals
text:
What the Hamlet Example Shows

That we can’t represent each of these conditionals with the same formalism.

title: 305 Lecture 13.1 - Two Kinds of Conditionals
section: What the Hamlet Example Doesn’t Show
text:
What the Hamlet Example Doesn’t Show

Where the boundary between these two types of conditionals is located. 
Whether there even is a binary distinction here, or whether this is part of some n-way division. 
How the difference is encoded in language. 
Whether it is really ‘if’ that is ambiguous, or something in the \(A\) or \(B\).

title: 305 Lecture 13.1 - Two Kinds of Conditionals
section: What is a Theory of Conditionals
text:
What is a Theory of Conditionals

It should cover both kinds, though maybe in different ways. 
You can read the truth tables as giving a very particular theory of conditionals. 
But it’s an incredibly implausible theory of conditionals.

title: 305 Lecture 13.1 - Two Kinds of Conditionals
text:
For Next Time
We’ll discuss the so called material conditional.

title: 305 Lecture 8.4 - Sampling without Replacement
text: To illustrate another special kind of updating on two data points: Sampling without Replacement

title: 305 Lecture 8.4 - Sampling without Replacement
text: To illustrate another special kind of updating on two data points: Sampling without Replacement

title: 305 Lecture 8.4 - Sampling without Replacement
text:
Associated Reading
Odds and Ends, Chapter 9

title: 305 Lecture 8.4 - Sampling without Replacement
text:
Dependence
What happens if the events \(B_1\) and \(B_2\) are dependent on one or other of the hypotheses?

The typical case is that they will be dependent on none or all of the hypotheses.
But it’s possible in principle to have independence on some and dependence on others.
And in that case we have to use the more complicated procedure I’m about to describe.

title: 305 Lecture 8.4 - Sampling without Replacement
text:
Sampling Without Replacement
The paradigm example of conditional dependence is sampling without replacement.

Assume you know which urn I’m using.
Then the draws without replacement won’t be independent because every time you draw a marble, there are fewer marbles of that color to draw the next time.

title: 305 Lecture 8.4 - Sampling without Replacement
text:
Example
Assume that I am using urn A. (Or assume that we are working out conditional probabilities conditional on urn A.)

For the first draw, the probability of red is 4 in 10, or 0.4.
Conditional on the first draw being red, the probability of the second draw being red is 3 in 9, or \(\frac{1}{3}\).
That’s because there are now 9 marbles left, and 3 of them are red.

title: 305 Lecture 8.4 - Sampling without Replacement
text:
Continuing the Example
So to work out the probability of some sequence of draws \(D_1, D_2\) given a hypothesis \(X\) about the urn, we need to use the more complicated rule.
\[
\Pr(D_1 \wedge D_2 | X) = \Pr(D_1 | X) \Pr(D_2 | X \wedge D_1)
\]
For example \[
\Pr(Red_1 \wedge Red_2 | A) = \Pr(Red_1 | A)\Pr(Red_2 | A \wedge Red_1) = \frac{4}{10} \times \frac{3}{9} = \frac{2}{15}
\]

title: 305 Lecture 8.4 - Sampling without Replacement
text:
Continuing the Example
So to work out the probability of some sequence of draws \(D_1, D_2\) given a hypothesis \(X\) about the urn, we need to use the more complicated rule.
\[
\Pr(D_1 \wedge D_2 | X) = \Pr(D_1 | X) \Pr(D_2 | X \wedge D_1)
\]
For example \[
\Pr(Red_1 \wedge Red_2 | B) = \Pr(Red_1 | B)\Pr(Red_2 | B \wedge Red_1) = \frac{8}{10} \times \frac{7}{9} = \frac{28}{45}
\]

title: 305 Lecture 8.4 - Sampling without Replacement
text:
Another Example
There are two urns in front of us.

One of them - urn A - has 4 red marbles, 3 green marbles, and 3 blue marbles.
The other - urn B- has 8 red marbles, 1 green marbles and 1 blue marbles. 

One of the urns will be selected at random, and then two marbles drawn from it without replacement.

If both draws are red, what is the probability that Urn A was selected?










Red-Red




Urn A
\(0.5 \times \frac{4}{10} \times \frac{3}{9} = \frac{1}{15}\)






Urn B
\(0.5 \times \frac{8}{10} \times \frac{7}{9} = \frac{14}{45}\)






Total
\(\frac{1}{15} + \frac{14}{45} = \frac{17}{45}\)



\[
\Pr(A | Red-Red) = \frac{\Pr(A \wedge Red-Red)}{\Pr(Red-Red)} = \frac{\frac{1}{15}}{\frac{17}{45}} = \frac{3}{17}
\]
The probability of Urn A fell by a bit more.

title: 305 Lecture 8.4 - Sampling without Replacement
text:
Yet Another Example
There are two urns in front of us.

One of them - urn A - has 4 red marbles, 3 green marbles, and 3 blue marbles.
The other - urn B- has 8 red marbles, 1 green marbles and 1 blue marbles. 

One of the urns will be selected at random, and then two marbles drawn from it with replacement.

If the first draw is red and the second green, what is the probability that Urn A was selected?

title: 305 Lecture 8.4 - Sampling without Replacement
text:
The General Conjunction Rule
To work out the probability of some sequence of draws \(D_1, D_2\) given a hypothesis \(X\) about the urn, we need to use the more complicated rule. \[
\Pr(D_1 \wedge D_2 | X) = \Pr(D_1 | X) \Pr(D_2 | X \wedge D_1)
\]
So in this case we get \[
\Pr(Red_1 \wedge Green_2 | A) = \Pr(Red_1 | A)\Pr(Green_2 | A \wedge Red_1) = \frac{4}{10} \times \frac{3}{9} = \frac{2}{15}
\]

title: 305 Lecture 8.4 - Sampling without Replacement
text:
The General Conjunction Rule
To work out the probability of some sequence of draws \(D_1, D_2\) given a hypothesis \(X\) about the urn, we need to use the more complicated rule. \[
\Pr(D_1 \wedge D_2 | X) = \Pr(D_1 | X) \Pr(D_2 | X \wedge D_1)
\]
And for Urn B we get \[
\Pr(Red_1 \wedge Green_2 | B) = \Pr(Red_1 | B)\Pr(Green_2 | B \wedge Red_1) = \frac{8}{10} \times \frac{1}{9} = \frac{4}{45}
\]









Red-Green




Urn A
\(0.5 \times \frac{4}{10} \times \frac{3}{9} = \frac{1}{15}\)






Urn B
\(0.5 \times \frac{8}{10} \times \frac{1}{9} = \frac{2}{45}\)






Total
\(\frac{1}{15} + \frac{2}{45} = \frac{5}{45}\)



\[
\Pr(A | Red-Green) = \frac{\Pr(A \wedge Red-Green)}{\Pr(Red-Green)} = \frac{\frac{1}{15}}{\frac{5}{45}} = \frac{3}{5}
\]
Which, interestingly, is exactly the same as in the with replacement case.

title: 305 Lecture 8.4 - Sampling without Replacement
text:
For Next Time
We’ll end the week with one last example.

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text: To discuss the strict conditional.

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text: To discuss the strict conditional.

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
Associated Reading

Boxes and Diamonds, section 6.3

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
Definition of Strict Conditional

If A, B means Necessarily, A materially implies B.
In symbols, \(A \rightarrow B = \Box (A \supset B)\)

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
What Box
Two main options

Universal - \(\Box (A \supset B)\) means that every \(A\) world is a \(B\) world, i.e., \(A \wedge \neg B\) is impossible.
Epistemic \(\Box (A \supset B)\) means that every \(A\) world that could be actual for all we know is a \(B\) world, i.e., \(A \wedge \neg B\) is known to be false.

And there are other complications you could try. We’ll mostly stay out of these.

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
The Nine Puzzle Cases

Modus Ponens - \(A, A \rightarrow B \vDash B\)
Agglomeration - \(A \rightarrow B, A \rightarrow C \vDash A \rightarrow (B \wedge C)\)
Transitive - \(A \rightarrow B, B \rightarrow C \vDash A \rightarrow C\)
Contraposition - \(A \rightarrow B \vDash \neg B \rightarrow \neg A\)
Antecedent Strengthening - \(A \rightarrow B \vDash (A \wedge C) \rightarrow B\)
Paradox 1 - \(B \vDash A \rightarrow B\)
Paradox 2 - \(\neg A \vDash A \rightarrow B\)
Strict Paradox - \(\Box B \vDash A \rightarrow B\)
Disjunction Paradox - \((A \rightarrow B) \vee (B \rightarrow A)\)

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
Modus Ponens
Still valid.

Assume \(A\), and that every \(A\) world is a \(B\) world.
Then this is an \(A\) world, so it is a \(B\) world.

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
Agglomeration.
Still valid.

Assume every \(A\) world is a \(B\) world, and that every \(A\) world is a \(C\) world.
Then every \(A\) world will be a \(B \wedge C\) world.
So \(A \rightarrow (B \wedge C)\)

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
Transitivity
Still valid.

Assume every \(A\) world is a \(B\) world, and every \(B\) world is a \(C\) world.
Then every \(A\) world is a \(C\) world.
So \(A \rightarrow C\)

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
Contraposition
Still valid.

Assume every \(A\) world is a \(B\) world.
Consider an arbitrary \(\neg B\) world.
It can’t be an \(A\) world, because then some \(A\) world would not be a \(B\) world.
So it’s a \(\neg A\) world.
So all \(\neg B\) worlds are \(\neg A\) worlds
So \(\neg B \rightarrow \neg A\).

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
Antecedent Strengthening
Still valid.

Assume every \(A\) world is a \(B\) world.
Consider an \(A \wedge C\) world.
It’s an \(A\) world, by the rule for true \(\wedge\).
So it’s a \(B\) world.
So \((A \wedge C) \rightarrow B\).

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
Paradox 1
Not valid!

Even if \(B\) is true, as long as \(A \wedge \neg B\) is possible, \(A \rightarrow B\) will be false.

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
Paradox 2
Not valid!

Even if \(A\) is not actually true, as long as some world make \(A \wedge \neg B\) true, then \(A \rightarrow B\) will be false.

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
Strict Paradox
Still valid.

Assume every world is a \(B\) world.
Then every \(A\) world is a world, and hence a \(B\) world.
So \(A \rightarrow B\).

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
Disjunction Paradox
Not valid.

Just let \(A, B\) be two independent propositions, so all four binary possibilities are realised.
Then neither disjunction will be true.

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
Summary
This is better than the material conditional theory, but not perfect. And we haven’t said anything about the subjunctive conditionals.

title: 305 Lecture 13.3 - Strict Conditionals
text:
For Next Time
We’ll talk a bit more about one of these rules, antecedent strengthening.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text: To discuss the conditional from propositional logic, the material conditional.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text: To discuss the conditional from propositional logic, the material conditional.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
Associated Reading

Boxes and Diamonds, section 6.1-6.2

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
What is It
The material conditional is what the truth tables say is the conditional.

We will write it as \(A \supset B\)
This just means \(\neg (A \wedge \neg B)\), i.e., \(\neg A \vee B\).

One interesting hypothesis is that this is the right way to interpret English language conditionals.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
What About Hamlet
Perhaps we should say that two interesting hypotheses are that the two kinds of English language conditionals are best represented as material conditionals.

Hypothesis 1: If it were the case that \(A\) it would be the case that \(B\) = \(A \supset B\).
Hypothesis 2: If it is the case that \(A\) then it is the case that \(B\) = \(A \supset B\).

The first of these is wildly implausible; the second is a bit more defensible.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
Material Subjunctives?
How can you complete this sentence so that it is true?

If the United States had entered World War II in 1939, then … 

On the material conditional theory, any sentence whatsoever you put in place of the dots will make this true. That’s not very plausible.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
Material Indicatives

But the material conditional theory is at least a little plausible for indicative conditionals.
At least, some smart people have defended it

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
Nine Formal Properties

Modus Ponens - \(A, A \rightarrow B \vDash B \pause\)
Agglomeration - \(A \rightarrow B, A \rightarrow C \vDash A \rightarrow (B \wedge C)\pause\)
Transitive - \(A \rightarrow B, B \rightarrow C \vDash A \rightarrow C\pause\)
Contraposition - \(A \rightarrow B \vDash \neg B \rightarrow \neg A\)
Antecedent Strengthening - \(A \rightarrow B \vDash (A \wedge C) \rightarrow B\)
Paradox 1 - \(B \vDash A \rightarrow B\)
Paradox 2 - \(\neg A \vDash A \rightarrow B\)
Strict Paradox - \(\Box B \vDash A \rightarrow B\)
Disjunction Paradox - \((A \rightarrow B) \vee (B \rightarrow A)\)

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
Nursery Rhyme
For want of a nail the shoe was lost.
For want of a shoe the horse was lost.
For want of a horse the rider was lost.
For want of a rider the message was lost.
For want of a message the battle was lost.
For want of a battle the kingdom was lost.
And all for the want of a horseshoe nail.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
As An Argument

If we hadn’t lost the nail, we wouldn’t have lost the shoe.
If we hadn’t lost the shoe, we wouldn’t have lost the horse.
If we hadn’t lost the horse, we wouldn’t have lost the rider
If we hadn’t lost the rider, we wouldn’t have lost the message
If we hadn’t lost the message, we wouldn’t have lost the battle
If we hadn’t lost the battle, we wouldn’t have lost the kingdom. 
So, if we hadn’t lost the nail, we wouldn’t have lost the kingdom.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
Nine Formal Properties

Modus Ponens - \(A, A \rightarrow B \vDash B\)
Agglomeration - \(A \rightarrow B, A \rightarrow C \vDash A \rightarrow (B \wedge C)\)
Transitive - \(A \rightarrow B, B \rightarrow C \vDash A \rightarrow C\)
Contraposition - \(A \rightarrow B \vDash \neg B \rightarrow \neg A \pause\)
Antecedent Strengthening - \(A \rightarrow B \vDash (A \wedge C) \rightarrow B \pause\)
Paradox 1 - \(B \vDash A \rightarrow B\pause\)
Paradox 2 - \(\neg A \vDash A \rightarrow B\pause\)
Strict Paradox - \(\Box B \vDash A \rightarrow B\pause\)
Disjunction Paradox - \((A \rightarrow B) \vee (B \rightarrow A)\)

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
Modus Ponens

Imagine that in some NCAA tournament, the only Big 10 teams left in the last 16 are Michigan and Ohio State.
And in this sport, Michigan is pretty good, while Ohio State is super lucky to make the last 16. 

Now consider the following two conditionals.

If a Big Ten team wins, then if it isn’t Michigan, it will be Ohio State.
If Michigan doesn’t win, Ohio State will win.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
Modus Ponens Counterexample?
Vann McGee made the following argument.

Conditional 1 is true, almost by definition. 
Conditional 2 is false. 
And those judgments stay correct even if it turns out that a Big Ten team does in fact win (especially if it is Michigan). 
In general, \(A \rightarrow (B \rightarrow C)\) and \(A\) seem like they can be true but (especially when \(A\) is not known) \(B \rightarrow C\) can seem false.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
Agglomeration

This is very hard to find intuitive counterexamples to.
Take this to be a challenge.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
Transitivity

This often sound right if you run the examples in that order.
But it can sound very bad if you don’t.

For example:

If I win the lottery tonight, I’ll be very happy.
If I get hit by a car on the way home and win the lottery tonight, then I’ll win the lottery tonight.
So if I get hit by a car on the way home and win the lottery tonight, I’ll be very happy.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
Contraposition
Some of the examples to this can sound a little silly, but still they arguably do sound like English.

If we win this election, we won’t win it by a lot.
So if we win by a lot, we won’t win.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
Antecedent Strengthening
The same cases that are problems for transitivity are problems here.

If I win the lottery tonight, I’ll be very happy.
So if I get hit by a car on the way home and win the lottery tonight, I’ll be vey happy

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
The Paradoxes

These are fairly easy to generate intuitive counterexamples for.
Note in particular that the disjunction one allows for \(B = \neg A\).
So we get the following: Either if we win, we’ll lose, or if we lose, we’ll win.

title: 305 Lecture 13.2 - Material Conditionals
text:
For Next Time
We’ll discuss the so called strict conditional.

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text: This lecture walks through a worked example of how to use probability trees to calculate a probability.

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text: This lecture walks through a worked example of how to use probability trees to calculate a probability.

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text:
Associated Reading
Odds and Ends, section 1.2.

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text:
Soccer Tournament
There is a big soccer tournament this weekend. The teams competing are

Fireflies
Penguins
Huskies
Bluebirds

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text:
Tournament Structure
There will be three games.

Fireflies vs Penguins
Huskies vs Bluebirds
Winner of Game 1 vs Winner of Game 2

Each game will have a winner one way or the other (maybe via penalty kicks or extra time).

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text:
Team Strength
The teams are not all equally good. They each have a ‘strength’. Here is their respective strengths



Team
Strength




Fireflies
5


Penguins
4


Huskies
3


Bluebirds
1

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text:
Win Probabilities
If a team with strength \(x\) plays a team with strength \(y\), the team with strength \(x\) will win with probability
\[
\frac{x}{x+ y}
\]
And the team with strength \(y\) will win with probability
\[
\frac{y}{x + y}
\]

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text:
Question
What is the probability that each team will win the tournament?


We will answer this by doing a tree.

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text:
Tournament Tree
Now we have to add the probabilities to it.

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text:
Tournament Tree
The first game is strength 5 vs strength 4, so the win probability for the stronger team is \(\nicefrac{5}{5+4}\), i.e., \(\nicefrac{5}{9}\).

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text:
Tournament Tree
The second game is strength 3 vs strength 1, so the win probability for the stronger team is \(\nicefrac{3}{3+1}\), i.e., \(\nicefrac{3}{4}\). And it doesn’t matter how the first game went - that’s the probability for the second game.

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text:
Tournament Tree
And now for each possible match up in game 3, we apply the formula to get the win probability for each team.

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text:
Tournament Tree

The probability of each completed branch is the product of each of the smaller branches.
So the one I’ve marked is \(
icefrac{4}{9} 	imes 
icefrac{3}{4} 	imes 
icefrac{3}{7} = 
icefrac{1}{7}\).

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
text:
Tournament Tree
I’ve included all the others - they usually don’t cancel as nicely as that one.

title: 305 Lecture 6.4 - A Worked Out Probability Tree
