title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text: We’re going discuss how to read, and understand, a truth table.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text: We’re going discuss how to read, and understand, a truth table.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, chapters 9-11

Note that I’m really introducing things in different order to the book.
We will end up in the same spot, but the aim here is not to simply repeat what’s in the book.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
Conceptual Idea


Think about all the combinations of truth values for the atomic sentences in a longer sentence, or in an argument.
For each possible combination, evaluate the truth of every part of every sentence in an argument.
See if it is possible for the premises to be true and the conclusion false.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
Truth Tables and Validity


If an argument is invalid, there will be one combination of values where the premises are true and the conclusion false.
If there is no such combination, mark the argument valid.
If there is such a combination, tentatively mark the argument invalid.
We’ll come back to why ‘tentatively’.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
Structure

We list each of the combinations in separate rows.
In each column we list the truth value of the sentence such that the symbol at the top of that column is the main connective.
That’s I think a lot easier to understand in practice than in theory, so let’s start with some examples.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text: A Truth Table

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
One Sentence
This is a truth table for a single sentence, not an argument. We’ll get to arguments in a bit.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
Understanding
We will also get (even sooner) to how to build these monsters. What I first want to talk about is how to read them.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
Four Rows
Each of the four rows represent a way things could be. For instance, the second row (in blue here) represents how things are if \(P\) is true and \(Q\) is false.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
Four Rows
There are four rows because there are 2 sentence letters - \(P\) and \(Q\) - each of which could take 2 values, so there are \(2 \times 2 = 4\) combinations of values.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
More Rows!

If there had been three sentence letters, there would be eight rows.
Four sentence letters would mean 16 rows, etc.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
The Columns

The columns under the letters reflect the value of the atomic sentences in each row.
As you can see, they are just cut-and-paste from the left hand side.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
Atomic Columns
I’ve put in blue all the truth values for \(P\), which as you can see were just copied and pasted from the columns on the far left.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
Intermediate Sentences
The surprising thing (or at least the thing that surprised me as a student) was what we mean by the column under the \(\rightarrow\), which I’ve put in blue.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
Intermediate Sentences
Each letter here is giving the truth value of the sentence that has that first \(\rightarrow\) as its main connective. That is, \(P \rightarrow Q\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
Intermediate Sentences
And this column gives the truth values for \(Q \rightarrow P\).

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
Conditionals
Don’t worry for now about why we write those letters down; we’ll get to that in the next lecture. For now I just want to go over how to read these tables.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
The Big Red Column

And the column that I’ve put in red gives the truth value of the sentence whose main connective is \(\vee\).
That is, in this case, the whole sentence.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
The Big Red Column
Ultimately the red column is all we really care about - the others are essentially scaffolding.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
Logical Truth

There is something distinctive about this table - the red column is all T.
That means the sentence is a logical truth.
We’ll have more to say about this presently in future lectures.

title: 305 Lecture 2.4 - Understanding Truth Tables
text:
For Next Time
We’ll talk about how to build truth tables.

title: 305 Lecture 4.1 - Using Truth Trees
text: Showing how we use truth trees to check for logical truth and validity.

title: 305 Lecture 4.1 - Using Truth Trees
text: Showing how we use truth trees to check for logical truth and validity.

title: 305 Lecture 4.1 - Using Truth Trees
text:
Reading
Boxes and Diamonds, section 2.4.

title: 305 Lecture 4.1 - Using Truth Trees
text:
Closure

A tree without branches closes if there is a sentence on the tree that is marked as both true and false.
Here is an example. The first line is stipulated, the rest are derived.

title: 305 Lecture 4.1 - Using Truth Trees
text:
Interpreting Closure

If a tree is closed, it means the initial assumptions can’t be true.
So this tree means that the initial assumption \(A \wedge \neg A\) can’t be true.

title: 305 Lecture 4.1 - Using Truth Trees
text:
Closure with Branches

A branching tree closes if every branch closes.
The next slide has an example, with in this case the top two lines stipulated.

title: 305 Lecture 4.1 - Using Truth Trees
text:
Closure with Branches

A tree with any open branches is open, i.e., not closed.
If a tree has some open branches and some closed branches, it is open.
All that matters is if all branches are closed.
The next slide is an example of an open tree.

title: 305 Lecture 4.1 - Using Truth Trees
text:
Logical Truth
Here is the algorithm for seeing whether a sentence is a logical truth.


Start a tree by saying at line 1 that the sentence is False.
If the tree closes, it is a logical truth.
If the tree does not close, it is not a logical truth (of propositional logic).

title: 305 Lecture 4.1 - Using Truth Trees
text:
Looking for Counterexamples (Tables)

Truth tables didn’t just tell us that something failed to be a logical truth (of propositional logic).
It told us where the failure was.
You didn’t just know that there was an in the relevant column, you knew which row it was on.
And that told you where to look for counterexamples.

title: 305 Lecture 4.1 - Using Truth Trees
text:
Looking for Counterexamples (Trees)

The same thing happens with trees.
By reading off the open branch, you can see where the sentence fails.
The trick is to focus on the atomic sentences on the branch.
These are the ones with no connectives at all.



The right hand branch doesn’t close.
The atomics on that branch are that \(A\) is and \(B\) is .
So that’s the line on the truth table where \(A \rightarrow (A \wedge B)\) is .

title: 305 Lecture 4.1 - Using Truth Trees
text:
Validity
Here is the algorithm for seeing whether an argument is valid (in propositional logic).


Start a tree with one line for each premise, saying that the premise is True.
Then have a line that says the conclusion is False.
If the tree closes, the argument is valid.
If the tree does not close, the argumnt is not valid (in propositional logic).

title: 305 Lecture 4.1 - Using Truth Trees
text:
For Next Time
We will illustrate this algorithm.

title: 305 Lecture 4.5 - The Idea of a Proof
text: This lecture introduces the basic idea of proofs

title: 305 Lecture 4.5 - The Idea of a Proof
text: This lecture introduces the basic idea of proofs

title: 305 Lecture 4.5 - The Idea of a Proof
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, section 16.1.

title: 305 Lecture 4.5 - The Idea of a Proof
text:
A Proof





Premises




Starts with premises.
In the system we’re working in, these are offset by a horizontal line.

title: 305 Lecture 4.5 - The Idea of a Proof
text:
A Proof

A proof ends when you get to the sentence you were aiming for.
This is different to tables, where you have to fill in everything.
And it is different to trees, where you have to either close all branches, or tick all lines.
Instead, proofs end when they have done their job.
In most cases, you could continue; you just choose not to.

title: 305 Lecture 4.5 - The Idea of a Proof
text:
Get To?

How do we ‘get’ from premises to where we want to go?
There are rules that allow us to generate new lines from old lines.
The premises are lines we can use for this purpose, but they aren’t the only ones.
Indeed, once the proof starts, that horizontal line carving off premises from conclusions does very little work.

title: 305 Lecture 4.5 - The Idea of a Proof
text:
Rules

Mostly, the rules come in pairs, two for each connective.
They will be called introduction and elimination rules.
Very roughly, the introduction rules are for when the connective appears in the desired conclusion, and the elimination rules are for when the connective appears in a premise.
But this is only rough - the rules are just rules.

title: 305 Lecture 4.5 - The Idea of a Proof
text:
Reiteration

The first rule the book introduces, in 16.2, is one of the rare rules that is not an introduction or elimination rule.
It says that you are allowed to repeat yourself.
If a line appears somewhere, it can get repeated later.

title: 305 Lecture 4.5 - The Idea of a Proof
text:
Why Reiteration

It turns out it has some technical uses.
But really it is mostly so we can make the arguments sound more like real life.
In real arguments, if you argue for p, then three paragraphs later argue for if p, q, you might remind the audience that p, rather than just immediately infer q.
That reminder is just reiteration.

title: 305 Lecture 4.5 - The Idea of a Proof
text:
For Next Time

We will look at 16.3, on the rules for ‘and’.

text: We’re going to look at how to translate English sentences into a form where we can use the tools of propositional logic on them.

title: 305 Lecture 2.2 - Forms in Propositional Logic

Associated Reading
forall x, chapter 5, “Connectives”

Note that the book goes into more detail than I’m going into here about the range of English sentences that can be translated (or at least symbolized) using the tools of propositional logic.

title: 305 Lecture 2.2 - Forms in Propositional Logic
text:
Sentence Letters

We use letters, usually starting with \(p\) and then continuing through the alphabet, for ‘atomic’ sentences.
forall x uses capital letters, others use lowercase. This is a matter of taste.

title: 305 Lecture 2.2 - Forms in Propositional Logic
text:
Symbols

“and” is represented by \(\wedge\)
“or” is represented by \(\vee\)
“not” is represented by \(\neg\)
“if” is represented by \(\rightarrow\)
“if and only if” is represented by \(\leftrightarrow\)

title: 305 Lecture 2.2 - Forms in Propositional Logic
text:
An Easy Example

It will rain on Monday or it will rain on Tuesday

Basic Sentences

\(M\) = It will rain on Monday
\(T\) = It will rain on Tuesday

Translation

\(M \vee T\)

title: 305 Lecture 2.2 - Forms in Propositional Logic
text:
Another Easy Example

It will rain on Monday and it will rain on Tuesday

Basic Sentences

\(M\) = It will rain on Monday
\(T\) = It will rain on Tuesday

Translation

\(M \wedge T\)

title: 305 Lecture 2.2 - Forms in Propositional Logic
text:
Only Slightly Harder Example

If it rains on Monday, it will rain on Tuesday

Basic Sentences

\(M\) = It will rain on Monday
\(T\) = It will rain on Tuesday

Translation

\(M \rightarrow T\)

title: 305 Lecture 2.2 - Forms in Propositional Logic
text:
And A Bit Harder Again

It will rain on Monday, but it won’t rain on Tuesday

Basic Sentences

\(M\) = It will rain on Monday
\(T\) = It will rain on Tuesday

Translation

\(M \wedge \neg T\)

title: 305 Lecture 2.2 - Forms in Propositional Logic
text:
Parentheses

As in math, these tell you what order to compute things in.
They let you avoid the ambiguity in the following sentence.


It will rain on Monday and it will rain on Tuesday or it will rain on Wednesday.

title: 305 Lecture 2.2 - Forms in Propositional Logic
text:
Two Translations
Basic Sentences

\(M\) = It will rain on Monday
\(T\) = It will rain on Tuesday
\(W\) = It will rain on Wednesday

Translations

\((M \wedge T) \vee W\)
\(M \wedge (T \vee W)\)

title: 305 Lecture 2.2 - Forms in Propositional Logic
text:
What’s the Difference?

\((M \wedge T) \vee W\)
\(M \wedge (T \vee W)\)

What is a situation where one of these is true but not the other?


If it only rains on Wednesday, then 1 is true but 2 is false.
Are there any others?

title: 305 Lecture 2.2 - Forms in Propositional Logic
text:
For Next Time
We’ll look at how the processes I’ve described in this lecture can be iterated.

title: 305 Lecture 4.7 - Rules for If
text: This lecture introduces the two rules for \(\rightarrow\).

title: 305 Lecture 4.7 - Rules for If
text: This lecture introduces the two rules for \(\rightarrow\).

title: 305 Lecture 4.7 - Rules for If
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, section 16.4.

title: 305 Lecture 4.7 - Rules for If
text:
Reasoning from If sentences
Here is the most basic kind of logical reasoning there is.

If it is snowing in Ann Arbor, then Brian is cold.
It is snowing in Ann Arbor.
So, Brian is cold.

title: 305 Lecture 4.7 - Rules for If
text:
If-Elimination

If-elimination, or \(\rightarrow\)E, is the formal version of the idea behind the last slide.
It takes a pair of lines as input.
One of those lines says \(X \rightarrow Y\).
The other says \(X\).
And you infer \(Y\).

title: 305 Lecture 4.7 - Rules for If
text:
If-Elimination



If-Elimination

title: 305 Lecture 4.7 - Rules for If
text:
Reasoning To an If-Sentence

Here’s one way to convince someone that If A, B is true.
Ask them to suppose, or imagine, or assume, that A is true.
Show that, given that supposition/imagination/assumption, we can infer that B is also true.
From the possibility of that kind of inference, infer If A, B is true.

title: 305 Lecture 4.7 - Rules for If
text:
If-Introduction

If-introduction, or \(\rightarrow\)I, is the formal version of the idea behind the last slide.
It says that if you make an assumption \(A\), and infer \(B\) from that assumption, you can conclude \(A \rightarrow B\)

title: 305 Lecture 4.7 - Rules for If
text:
Assumptions

So to do this we need to have a technique for making assumptions.
The idea is that we indent the proof by a few spaces (to make clear that everything we do is suppositional), and put a line under the new assumption (to make clear what we’re assuming).

title: 305 Lecture 4.7 - Rules for If
text:
Assumptions





An example of an assumption




In this proof, \(R\) is the only premise.
Then \(L\) is an assumption.
If we can get from \(L\) to \(X\), we can infer \(L \rightarrow X\)

title: 305 Lecture 4.7 - Rules for If
text:
Discharging Assumptions





A proof using \(\rightarrow\)I




Note that the last line is not indented.
And there is a dash, not a comma, between the line numbers.
We are back in the main proof, reasoning from the ‘sub-proof’.

title: 305 Lecture 4.7 - Rules for If
text:
If-Introduction



If-Introduction

title: 305 Lecture 4.7 - Rules for If
text:
For Next Time

Next week we will start by looking in more detail at these subproofs, how they work, and what restrictions we have to put on them.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
text: This lecture introduces the rules we use for building up truth trees.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
text: This lecture introduces the rules we use for building up truth trees.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
text:
Associated Reading
Boxes and Diamonds, sections 2.2-2.3.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
text:
What Rules Do
The rules tell you what new lines to write down given the lines you’ve already got.

To some extent they simply have to be memorised.
But hopefully they are all (except for the rules about \(\rightarrow\)) fairly intuitive.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
text:
Rules for \(\neg\)








Note that the line numbers are just for illustration, and are arbitrary in two senses.
First, you apply the rule wherever a sentence like \(\neg A\) appears, not just at line 1.
Second, you don’t need to apply the rules immediately, so the successor line could come later than 2.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
text:
Rule for true \(\wedge\) sentence
When you have a true \(\wedge\) sentence, you can write down that the sentences either side of it are true.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
text:
Rule for true \(\vee\) sentence

When you have a true \(\vee\) sentence, you create two branches.
The way to read the tree is that at least one of the branches must be all true. 
The ‘trunk’ above the branching (in this case just line 1), is part of both branches.
Branches are inclusive; you are saying that at least one branch is true, not that precisely one is.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
text:
Rule for false \(\wedge\) sentence

If an \(\wedge\) sentence is false, then we know that one or other (or both) of the sides are false.
So we create two branches, one where each side is false.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
text:
Rule for false \(\vee\) sentence
When you have a false \(\vee\) sentence, you know that each side is false, so you write down that they are both false.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
section: Justifying the rule for false \(\vee\) sentences
text:
Justifying the rule for false \(\vee\) sentences
Recall the truth table for \(\vee\)

The only line where the whole sentence is is line 4.
So if a \(\vee\) sentence is , we know that we’re on line 4.
And on line 4, both \(A\) and \(B\) are false.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
text:
Rule for false \(\rightarrow\) sentence
When you have a false \(\rightarrow\) sentence, you know that the left side is true and the right side is false, so you write those things down.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
section: Justifying the rule for false \(\rightarrow\) sentences
text:
Justifying the rule for false \(\rightarrow\) sentences
Recall the truth table for \(\rightarrow\)

The only line where the whole sentence is is line 2.
So if a \(\rightarrow\) sentence is , we know that we’re on line 2.
And on line 4,\(A\) is true and \(B\) are false.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
text:
Rule for true \(\rightarrow\) sentence

When you have a true \(\rightarrow\) sentence, you create two branches.
On the first, \(A\) is false. That covers lines 3 and 4 of the truth table.
On the second, \(B\) is true. That covers lines 1 and 3 of the truth table.
Between them, they cover lines 1, 3 and 4 of the truth table.
And those are the lines where \(A \rightarrow B\) is true.

title: 305 Lecture 3.6 - Rules for Truth Trees
text:
Next Week

We will look at some examples of truth trees.
I find truth trees are much easier in practice than in theory, so if this was all a bit abstract, hopefully it will be more intelligible once we work through some examples.

title: 305 Lecture 7.5 - The Crashing Websites
text: This lecture will go over exercise 8.8 in the book, as an illustration of how to invert conditional probabilities in a slightly more complicated case.

title: 305 Lecture 7.5 - The Crashing Websites
text: This lecture will go over exercise 8.8 in the book, as an illustration of how to invert conditional probabilities in a slightly more complicated case.

title: 305 Lecture 7.5 - The Crashing Websites
text:
Associated Reading
Odds and Ends, Chapter 8

title: 305 Lecture 7.5 - The Crashing Websites
text:
Odds and Ends 8.8
A company makes websites, always powered by one of three server platforms: Bulldozer, Kumquat, or Penguin. Bulldozer crashes 1 out of every 10 visits, Kumquat crashes 1 in 50 visits, and Penguin only crashes 1 out of every 200 visits.
Half of the websites are run on Bulldozer, 30% are run on Kumquat, and 20% are run on Penguin.
You visit one of their sites for the first time and it crashes. What is the probability it was run on Penguin?

title: 305 Lecture 7.5 - The Crashing Websites
text:
Start with a Table




Crash
No Crash




Bulldozer




Kumquat




Penguin





We will start by filling in the table - though really it is the left hand column that matters here

title: 305 Lecture 7.5 - The Crashing Websites
text:
The Table




Crash
No Crash




Bulldozer
\(0.5 \times 0.1 = 0.05\)



Kumquat




Penguin





The formular for Bulldozer-and-Crash is
\[
\Pr(\text{Bulldozer}) \times \Pr(\text{Crash}|\text{Bulldozer}) = 0.5 \times 0.1 = 0.05
\]

title: 305 Lecture 7.5 - The Crashing Websites
text:
The Table




Crash
No Crash




Bulldozer
\(0.5 \times 0.1 = 0.05\)



Kumquat
\(0.3 \times 0.02 = 0.006\)



Penguin





The formula for Kumquat-and-Crash is
\[
\Pr(\text{Kumquat}) \times \Pr(\text{Crash}|\text{Kumquat}) = 0.3 \times 0.02 = 0.006
\]

title: 305 Lecture 7.5 - The Crashing Websites
text:
The Table




Crash
No Crash




Bulldozer
\(0.5 \times 0.1 = 0.05\)



Kumquat
\(0.3 \times 0.02 = 0.006\)



Penguin
\(0.2 \times 0.005 = 0.001\)




The formula for Penguin-and-Crash is
\[
\Pr(\text{Penguin}) \times \Pr(\text{Crash}|\text{Penguin}) = 0.2 \times 0.005 = 0.001
\]

title: 305 Lecture 7.5 - The Crashing Websites
text:
The Table




Crash
No Crash




Bulldozer
\(0.05\)



Kumquat
\(0.006\)



Penguin
\(0.001\)




Let’s rewrite it without the workings.

title: 305 Lecture 7.5 - The Crashing Websites
text:
The Table




Crash
No Crash




Bulldozer
\(0.05\)
\(0.45\)


Kumquat
\(0.006\)
\(0.294\)


Penguin
\(0.001\)
\(0.199\)



We can fill in the right-hand column by noting that the rows have to add up to 0.5, 0.3 and 0.2 respectively; since those are the probabilities of the three server types.

title: 305 Lecture 7.5 - The Crashing Websites
text:
Crash!




Crash
No Crash




Bulldozer
\(0.05\)
\(0.45\)


Kumquat
\(0.006\)
\(0.294\)


Penguin
\(0.001\)
\(0.199\)



So the probability of a crash is
\[
0.05 + 0.006 + 0.001 = 0.057
\]

title: 305 Lecture 7.5 - The Crashing Websites
text:
Penguin given Crash
So the probability of Penguin given Crash is
\[
\frac{\Pr(\text{Penguin-and-Crash})}{\Pr(\text{Crash})} = \frac{0.001}{0.057} \approx 0.0175
\]
That’s really low, because Penguin sites don’t crash.

title: 305 Lecture 7.5 - The Crashing Websites
text:
For Next Time

We will look at a formula that some people find helpful for solving these kinds of problems.

title: 305 Lecture 5.3 - Rules for Not
text: This lecture discusses the rules for negation.

title: 305 Lecture 5.3 - Rules for Not
text: This lecture discusses the rules for negation.

title: 305 Lecture 5.3 - Rules for Not
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, section 16.8.

title: 305 Lecture 5.3 - Rules for Not
text:
A New Symbol

\(\bot\)

Read this as ‘contradiction’, or ‘the false’. It is a sentence that can’t be true.

title: 305 Lecture 5.3 - Rules for Not
text:
Contradiction and Negation


How do we know that a contradiction has obtained?
By proving some sentence and the negation of that very sentence.
This is going to be our rule for proving things from a negation.

title: 305 Lecture 5.3 - Rules for Not
text:
Neg-Elimination



Neg-Elimination


From contradictory sentences, infer \(\bot\).

title: 305 Lecture 5.3 - Rules for Not
text:
How to Prove a Negation
Show that if the unnegated part were true, something absurd would follow.

title: 305 Lecture 5.3 - Rules for Not
text:
Absurdity


In engineering, a perpetual motion machine, or some other kind of free energy.
In finance, a risk-free way to make a guaranteed profit.
In logic, a sentence and its negation.

title: 305 Lecture 5.3 - Rules for Not
text:
Neg-Introduction



Neg-Introduction



If A implies a contradiction, infer \(\neg\)A.

title: 305 Lecture 5.3 - Rules for Not
text:
Indirect Proof



Indirect Proof



If \(\neg\)A implies a contradiction, infer A.

title: 305 Lecture 5.3 - Rules for Not
text:
Explosion



Explosion



A contradiction implies anything.
Note that this rule is redundant; we can replicate it using Indirect Proof.
I think they’ve added it because it is an interesting rule if you don’t like Indirect Proof.

title: 305 Lecture 5.3 - Rules for Not
text:
For Next Time

That’s a lot of rules we’ve set out.
We will start looking at how they work in practice.

title: 305 Lecture 7.6 - Bayes’s Theorem
text: This lecture will go over one of the most famous theorems in probability: Bayes’s Theorem.

title: 305 Lecture 7.6 - Bayes’s Theorem
text: This lecture will go over one of the most famous theorems in probability: Bayes’s Theorem.

title: 305 Lecture 7.6 - Bayes’s Theorem
text:
Associated Reading
Still chapter 8 of Odds and Ends

title: 305 Lecture 7.6 - Bayes’s Theorem
text:
One Important Equivalence
\[
\Pr(B | A) \Pr(A) = \Pr(A | B) \Pr(B)
\]
We know that because these are two different ways of expressing \(\Pr(A \wedge B)\).

title: 305 Lecture 7.6 - Bayes’s Theorem
text:
One Important Equivalence
Divide both sides by \(\Pr(B)\) (and flip sides around) and you get
\[
\Pr(A | B) = \frac{\Pr(B | A) \Pr(A)}{\Pr(B)}
\]
This is the formula that’s written in neon in the textbook.

title: 305 Lecture 7.6 - Bayes’s Theorem
text:
Another Important Equivalence
Start again with our canonical formula for conditional probability.
\[
\Pr(A | B) = \frac{\Pr(A \wedge B)}{\Pr(B)}
\]

title: 305 Lecture 7.6 - Bayes’s Theorem
text:
Another Important Equivalence
Replace \(\Pr(A \wedge B)\) with its definition in terms of conditional probability.
\[
\Pr(A | B) = \frac{\Pr(B | A)\Pr(A)}{\Pr(B)}
\]

title: 305 Lecture 7.6 - Bayes’s Theorem
text:
Another Important Equivalence
Now replace \(\Pr(B)\) with the formula we derived for it in an earlier lecture.
\[
\Pr(A | B) = \frac{\Pr(B | A)\Pr(A)}{\Pr(B | A)\Pr(A) + \Pr(B | \neg A)\Pr(\neg A)}
\]
And this is what is sometimes called Bayes’s Theorem.

title: 305 Lecture 7.6 - Bayes’s Theorem
text:
General Version

Let \(X_1, \dots, X_n\) be a partition of possibility space.
Then \(B\) is equivalent to \((B \wedge X_1) \vee \dots \vee (B \wedge X_n)\).
So \(\Pr(B) = \Pr(B \wedge X_1) + \dots + \Pr(B \wedge X_n)\)
And we can use that to get the very general form of Bayes’s theorem

title: 305 Lecture 7.6 - Bayes’s Theorem
text:
General Version
\[
\Pr(X_i | B) = \frac{\Pr(B | X_i)\Pr(X_i)}{\sum_{k=1}^n \Pr(B | X_k)\Pr(X_k)}
\]
So if you know the prior probability of each cell in the partition, and the probability of \(B\) conditional on each cell, you can work out the probability of being in a particular cell given \(B\).

title: 305 Lecture 7.6 - Bayes’s Theorem
text:
General Version

A lot of people make a big deal about this formula.
I rarely find myself in situations where it is easier to use than something like the trees or tables.
But the fact that so many people fuss so much about it suggests that for a lot of applications it is very helpful.
For the assignment questions where this is relevant, it’s totally up to you whether to use the formula, or trees, or tables.

title: 305 Lecture 5.2 - Or
text: This lecture discusses the rules for disjunction.

title: 305 Lecture 5.2 - Or
text: This lecture discusses the rules for disjunction.

title: 305 Lecture 5.2 - Or
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, section 16.7.

title: 305 Lecture 5.2 - Or
text:
Reasoning to an Or sentence
Imagine we’re trying to prove a disjunction, like this one:

Either Rémy made the soup, or Alfredo made the soup.

There are a lot of ways we could prove this, but the simplest would be to either prove Rémy made the soup, or prove Alfredo made the soup. Either one of those would do.

title: 305 Lecture 5.2 - Or
text:
Or-Introduction

Or-introduction, or \(\vee\)I, is the formal version of the idea behind the last slide.
It says that if you a sentence, you can add a disjunct either to the left of it or to the right of it.

title: 305 Lecture 5.2 - Or
text:
Or-Introduction the first



Or-Introduction

title: 305 Lecture 5.2 - Or
text:
Or-Introduction the second



Or-Introduction

title: 305 Lecture 5.2 - Or
text:
Reasoning from an Or Sentence
Say you have as a premise:

Either Rémy made the soup, or Alfredo made the soup.

And you want to get to the conclusion:

The soup is good.

What do you need?

title: 305 Lecture 5.2 - Or
text:
Two Things


You need an argument that if Rémy made the soup, it is good; and
You need an argument that if Alfredo made the soup, it is good.

title: 305 Lecture 5.2 - Or
text:
Or-Elimination



Or-Elimination

title: 305 Lecture 5.2 - Or
text:
Notes on Or Elimination


It is hard; you have to do two subproofs.
It doesn’t always eliminate the disjunction; sometimes the C sentence includes a disjunction






A distributive law






A metaphor

title: 305 Lecture 5.2 - Or
text:
For Next Time

We will look at the rules for negation.
Then we will turn to the hard question of how to build these proofs.

title: 305 Lecture 7.2 - Independence
text: A short lecture to introduce a big idea: the notion of independence.

title: 305 Lecture 7.2 - Independence
text: A short lecture to introduce a big idea: the notion of independence.

title: 305 Lecture 7.2 - Independence
text:
Associated Reading
Odds and Ends, Chapter 6.5

title: 305 Lecture 7.2 - Independence
text:
Independence
\(A\) and \(B\) are independent if (and only if)
\[
\Pr(A | B) = \Pr(A)
\]
That is, taking things conditional on \(B\) doesn’t change \(A\).

title: 305 Lecture 7.2 - Independence
text:
Ways Independence can Fail
Causal

\(B\) might be a possible cause of \(A\). 
\(B\) might be a possible preventer of \(A\). 
\(B\) might be a common effect of a frequent cause of \(A\). 
\(B\) might be a common effect of a frequent preventer of \(A\).

title: 305 Lecture 7.2 - Independence
text:
Ways Indepenence can Fail
Epistemic

\(B\) being true could tell you that a source that also predicts \(A\) is more reliable than you thought.

title: 305 Lecture 7.2 - Independence
section: Two Big Real World Facts about Independence
text:
Two Big Real World Facts about Independence

In reality, strict independence almost never obtains. 
In practice, it’s very often useful to assume independence for modelling purposes. 

These are consistent, but it does mean be careful. Sometimes assuming independence is like assuming that relativistic considerations aren’t important to figuring out whether a bridge will stand up. And sometimes it is like assuming that friction isn’t important to figuring out whether a bridge will stand up.

title: 305 Lecture 7.2 - Independence
text:
An Odd Instance of Independence
Two fair dice, one red and one blue, are going to be tossed. Let \(A\) be that the sum of what they show is 7. Let \(B\) be that the red die shows a 2.

Question

Are \(A\) and \(B\) independent?


Surprising answer - yes!

title: 305 Lecture 7.2 - Independence
text:
For Next Time

We will look at how to invert conditional probabilities, how to go from a bunch of facts of the form \(\Pr(A | B) = x\) to facts of the form \(\Pr(B | A) = y\).

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text: We’re discussing the nature of validity.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text: We’re discussing the nature of validity.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, chapter 2, “The Scope of Logic”.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Virtues of Arguments
What are some virtues of arguments that you can think of? What makes for a good argument?

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Virtues of Arguments


Premises are true.
Premises are known.
Premises are accepted in debate.
Premises are evidence for the conclusion.
Premises guarantee the truth of the conclusion.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Logic
To a first approximation, logic is about the last of these virtues.

Does the truth of a set of premises guarantee the truth of the conclusion? 
If so, we’ll say the argument is valid.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Guarantee
What is it for the premises to guarantee truth?

It’s for every case where the premises are true to also be a case where the conclusion is true. 
That’s nice, you might say, but what’s a case?

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Cases

This, I’m afraid, we’re going to leave a little abstract.
As the book in effect notes, it’s probably best to leave this as a placeholder.
Different notions of what a case are get you different notions of what arguments are valid.
But you get into deep metaphysical waters here pretty fast; let’s retreat to some defintions.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Terminology
When an argument, with premises \(P_1, P_2, \dots, P_n\) and conclusion \(C\) is valid, we’ll say all the following things are true. 

The premises entail the conclusion. 
The conclusion follows from the premises. 
The conclusion is a consequence of the premises.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Invalid

An argument is invalid just in case it is not valid. 
That is, it is invalid if there is a case where the premises are true and the conclusion false.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Structure

Logic is largely about validity, about which premises guarantee the truth of which conclusions.
It’s about a special kind of guarantee, one that holds in virtue of the structure or form of the premises and conclusion.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
A Valid Argument

 

All kangaroos are wise.

 

Skippy is a kangaroo.

\(\therefore\)

Skippy is wise.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Non-Structural Guarantee
Compare the Skippy argument with this one.

 

Today is Wednesday.

\(\therefore\)

Tomorrow is Thursday.


The premise guarantees the truth of the conclusion, but it does so in virtue of meanings of ‘Wednesday’ and ‘Thursday’, not structural features.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Form and Structure

In the book they talk about the form of arguments.
This is just the same thing as I’m meaning by structure.
There is something about the Skippy example that’s special; just the form of the argument shows that it is valid.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Structure and Substitution
When the structure of the argument does the guaranteeing, the guarantee would persist through some substitutions.

 

All kangaroos are wise.

 

Skippy is a kangaroo.

\(\therefore\)

Skippy is wise.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Structure and Substitution
When the structure of the argument does the guaranteeing, the guarantee would persist through some substitutions.

 

All kangaroos are wise.

 

Lucky is a kangaroo.

\(\therefore\)

Lucky is wise.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Structure and Substitution
When the structure of the argument does the guaranteeing, the guarantee would persist through some substitutions.

 

All koalas are wise.

 

Lucky is a koala.

\(\therefore\)

Lucky is wise.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Structure and Substitution
When the structure of the argument does the guaranteeing, the guarantee would persist through some substitutions.

 

All koalas are dishonest.

 

Lucky is a koala.

\(\therefore\)

Lucky is dishonest.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Terminology

We’ll say an argument is valid just in case the truth of the premises guarantees the truth of the conclusion.
We’ll say an argument is formally valid, or occasionally logically valid, if it is valid, and any argument with the same form/structure is valid.
We’ll say an argument is sound just in case it is valid and has true premises.
We won’t have much interest here in soundness; just in validity.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Structure

You might have noticed that I never actually defined what it is for two arguments to share a structure.
I just said that changing a name (consistently throughout the argument), or changing a noun/adjective (consistently) preserves structure.
But I didn’t say more than that.
Hold that thought! We’ll have quite a lot to say as the course goes on about this notion of structure.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
Validity
Here are some equivalent ways to define validity.

An argument is valid if necessarily, when the premises are true, the conclusion is too.
An argument is valid if it is impossible for the premises to be true and the conclusion to not be true.

We’ll use that last formulation a lot.

title: 305 Lecture 1.3 - Validity
text:
For Next Time
We’ll start our look at the most fundamental kind of logic: propositional logic.

title: 305 Lecture 3.1 - Propositional Logic
text: We’re introducing propositional logic, and talking about what it is.

title: 305 Lecture 3.1 - Propositional Logic
text: We’re introducing propositional logic, and talking about what it is.

title: 305 Lecture 3.1 - Propositional Logic
text:
Associated Reading
This doesn’t correspond to any particular part of the book, but I think it’s helpful before going onto chapter 12.

title: 305 Lecture 3.1 - Propositional Logic
text:
Key Assumption
We start with one key assumption:

Every sentence has precisely one of the two truth values: TRUE, FALSE.
I will write these values as \(\True\) and \(\False\).
I’m using these funny shaped letters because they get used in Boxes and Diamonds, and because they make our lives easier when we start using trees.

title: 305 Lecture 3.1 - Propositional Logic
text:
Unpacking the Assumption

There are just two truth values: \(\True\), \(\False\).

Every sentence has one of them. There are no truth-value gaps.
No sentence has both of them. There are no truth-value gluts.

title: 305 Lecture 3.1 - Propositional Logic
text:
Two Parts of Classical Logic

Traditionally, classical logic is divided into two parts.
We’re just going to look at the first part here.
The parts differ on what counts as a structural feature of a sentence.

title: 305 Lecture 3.1 - Propositional Logic
text:
Classical Propositional Logic
The structural features are just five sentential connectives:

And
Or
Not
If
If and only if; usually written iff.

The result is a very simple, but very weak, logic. It doesn’t even tell us that the arguments about Skippy and Lucky are structurally valid. (And note that here we’ll simplify further, by not covering iff.)

title: 305 Lecture 3.1 - Propositional Logic
text:
Classical Predicate Logic
As well as those structural features, we add:

The division of parts of sentences into names, variables, predicates, and logical terms.
The addition of the logical terms All and Some.

title: 305 Lecture 3.1 - Propositional Logic
text:
For Next Time

We will see how to use truth tables to tell which sentences are logical truths in propositional logic.

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text: This lecture discusses strategies for constructing proofs that involve working forwards.

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text: This lecture discusses strategies for constructing proofs that involve working forwards.

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, section 17.2.

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
Working Forwards
Big Idea: Plan to use the Elimination rules on the connectives in the premises.

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
Simple Illustration: And
When one of the premises is of the form \(X \wedge y\), you’ll almost certainly need to apply \(\wedge\)E to get \(X\) and \(Y\).

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
Slightly Trickier: If


When one of the premises is of the form \(X \rightarrow Y\), you’ll almost certainly need to apply \(\rightarrow\)E.
And that means you’ll need \(X\).
But in practice it’s hard to tell in advance whether you’ll prove \(X\), or have it as the start of a subproof, or something else.

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
Working forward from Or
When one of the premises is \(X \vee Y\) there is a clear(ish) strategy.

Find a target conclusion \(C\).
Do a subproof from \(X\) to \(C\).
Do a subproof from \(Y\) to \(C\).
Conclude \(C\) by \(\vee\)E.

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
Working forward from Or
Why clear-ish?

Because it isn’t always true that the target here should be the conclusion of the whole argument.
Sometimes it is optimal to do a step or two of working backwards first.
But if you want a simple rule to go by, the best is to do what’s on the previous slide with \(C\) as the conclusion of the whole argument.

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
\(A \vee B, B \rightarrow C \vdash A \vee C\)



Write Out Premises and Conclusion

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
\(A \vee B, B \rightarrow C \vdash A \vee C\)



Set Up \(\vee\)E

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
\(A \vee B, B \rightarrow C \vdash A \vee C\)



Note what happens on line 7

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
\(A \vee B, B \rightarrow C \vdash A \vee C\)



There are indents on all the blank lines

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
\(A \vee B, B \rightarrow C \vdash A \vee C\)



The left-hand subproof

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
\(A \vee B, B \rightarrow C \vdash A \vee C\)



The right-hand subproof

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
\(A \vee B, B \rightarrow C \vdash A \vee C\)



Finishing the proof - note the justifications

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
Proofs From Disjunctions

That’s the basic structure.
They are a bit of a pain; I’ve illustrated almost the easiest one I could find.
But it’s really important to keep track of what your goal is at every point.
For almost everyone, that’s impossible if you try to just start at line 1 and work to line 9.
You have to bounce forward and backward in these proofs; just like I’ve done here.

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
Working Forward from Not

It’s going to be some kind of proof involving \(\bot\).
Whether that’s Indirect Proof or \(\neg\)E isn’t always clear, but that’s going to be the structure.

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
A Simple Strategy

If any of the premises is negated, then assume the opposite of the conclusion and try to derive \(\bot\).
If the conclusion is positive, its opposite is adding a negation.
If the conclusion is already negated, its opposite is deleting the negation.

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
A More Complicated Strategy

Sometimes the simple strategy won’t be optimal.
Sometimes it will be quicker to do some working forward from the other premises, or backwards from the conclusion.
But the simple strategy is going to work, even in those cases.

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
\(\neg A \vdash \neg (A \wedge B)\)



Premise and Conclusion

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
\(\neg A \vdash \neg (A \wedge B)\)



Set up \(\neg\)I - note how \(\bot\) is written

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
\(\neg A \vdash \neg (A \wedge B)\)



Derive the contradiction

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
\(\neg A \vdash \neg (A \wedge B)\)



Finish the proof

title: 305 Lecture 5.5 - Strategies 2: Working Forwards
text:
For Next Time

I’ll end with two special techniques

title: 305 Lecture 7.1 - Conditional Probability
text: To introduce a key new concept: conditional probability.

title: 305 Lecture 7.1 - Conditional Probability
text: To introduce a key new concept: conditional probability.

title: 305 Lecture 7.1 - Conditional Probability
text:
Associated Reading
Odds and Ends, Chapter 6

title: 305 Lecture 7.1 - Conditional Probability
text:
What it is

Sometimes we don’t just care about how likely something is.
We care about how likely it is given some other thing has happened or will happen. 
This might be because we want to plan. 
It might be because we want to compute overall probabilities. 
Or it might be because we’ve found something out, and want to know what it means for other likelihoods.

title: 305 Lecture 7.1 - Conditional Probability
text:
Prior Examples
We’ve already used some conditional probabilities.

We already talked, for example, about the probability of the Fireflies winning conditional on them being in the final against the Bluebirds.

title: 305 Lecture 7.1 - Conditional Probability
text:
Inverting
But there are other questions we might want to ask as well.


E.g., conditional on the Fireflies winning, how likely is it that they played the Huskies.

title: 305 Lecture 7.1 - Conditional Probability
text:
Intuitions
This isn’t an easy question to answer intuitively.

It is more likely that the Huskies will be actually in the final - because they are the better team.
But it is more likely that the Fireflies will win against the Bluebirds - because they are weaker.
It isn’t always easy to intuitively balance these forces.

title: 305 Lecture 7.1 - Conditional Probability
text:
Formula
\[
\Pr(A | B) = \frac{Pr(A \wedge B)}{Pr(B)}
\]

The left-hand side means “The probability of \(A\) given \(B\).” 
And the right-hand side says that this is equal to the probability of \(A \wedge B\) divided by the probability of \(B\).

title: 305 Lecture 7.1 - Conditional Probability
text:
Fireflies
\[
\Pr(HR | FC) = \frac{\Pr(HR \wedge FC)}{\Pr(FC)}
\]
That is, the probability that the Huskies are runners-up (\(HR\)) given that the Fireflies are champions (\(FC\)), is given by the formula on the right.

title: 305 Lecture 7.1 - Conditional Probability
text:
Fireflies
\[
\Pr(HR | FC) = \frac{0.26}{0.26+0.116} = \frac{0.26}{0.376} \approx 0.691
\]
So conditional on the Fireflies winning, it’s just under 70% likely they beat the Huskies.

title: 305 Lecture 7.1 - Conditional Probability
text:
Updating
We are going to mostly assume that this philosophical claim is true.
\[
\Pr{}_B(A) = \Pr(A | B)
\]
The way to read that is saying that the unconditional probability of \(A\) after learning \(B\) equals the conditional probability of \(A\) given \(B\). This claim - and it is a philosophical claim not a mathematical one - is a big part of why we care about conditional probability.

title: 305 Lecture 7.1 - Conditional Probability
text:
For Next Time
We’re going to talk about when it is that two events are independent.

title: 305 Lecture 3.2 - Tautologies
text: This lecture is about how we use truth tables to check for whether something is a tautology.

title: 305 Lecture 3.2 - Tautologies
text: This lecture is about how we use truth tables to check for whether something is a tautology.

title: 305 Lecture 3.2 - Tautologies
text:
Associated Reading
forall x, chapter 12, especially section 12.1.

title: 305 Lecture 3.2 - Tautologies
text:
Tautologies
We are going to start with a particular kind of sentence, a tautology.

title: 305 Lecture 3.2 - Tautologies
text:
Definition
A tautology is a sentence that gets the value \(\True\) in every row of its truth table.

title: 305 Lecture 3.2 - Tautologies
text:
Examples of Tautologies
What are some sentences that might fit the bill?

title: 305 Lecture 3.2 - Tautologies
text: The Law of Excluded Middle

title: 305 Lecture 3.2 - Tautologies
text: The Law of Non-Contradiction

title: 305 Lecture 3.2 - Tautologies
text: Reflexive Conditionals

title: 305 Lecture 3.2 - Tautologies
text: A Surprising One

title: 305 Lecture 3.2 - Tautologies
text:
Tautologies and Logical Truth

All tautologies are logical truths.
But the converse isn’t true - some logical truths are not tautologies.
E.g., If Brian is necessarily a human, then Brian is a human.

title: 305 Lecture 3.2 - Tautologies
text:
For Next Time
We will start using truth tables to look at whether arguments are valid.

title: \(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\) (in KT)
text:
\(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\) is a theorem of KT.

So we can use all the rules, plus the special rules for T.

title: \(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\) (in KT)
text:
\(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\) is a theorem of KT.

So we can use all the rules, plus the special rules for T.

title: \(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\) (in KT)
text:
\(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\)
Start with it being false at 1.

title: \(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\) (in KT)
text:
\(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\)
You know the drill - left hand side true, right hand side false.

title: \(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\) (in KT)
text:
\(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\)
It’s T, so we have obligations when a \(\Box\) sentence is true.

title: \(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\) (in KT)
text:
\(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\)
Now we have to make the false \(\Box\) sentence actually false.

title: \(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\) (in KT)
text:
\(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\)
Carry down the true \(\Box\) sentence.

title: \(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\) (in KT)
text:
\(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\)

One more false \(\Box\) sentence. 
And now we’re done; all rules applied, and tree open. So it is not a theorem.

title: \(\Box A \rightarrow \Box \Box A\) (in KT)
text:
A Model

Three worlds, \(w_1, w_{1.1}, w_{1.1.1}\).
The accessibility relations are \(w_1Rw_{1.1}, w_{1.1}Rw_{1.1.1}, w_1Rw_1, w_{1.1}Rw_{1.1}\) and \(w_{1.1.1}Rw_{1.1.1}\).
The first two are from the tree, the next three from the restriction.
\(A\) is true at \(w_1\) and \(w_{1.1}\) and false at \(w_{1.1.1}\).
So \(\Box A\) will be true only at \(w_1\).
So \(\Box \Box A\) will be false at \(w_1\), as required.
